stem: For 0.035" GMAW wire, which contact tip size (standard fit) should be used?

choices.text: 10,000 rpm — it'll be fine for short cuts

rationales.CHOICE-2: 13,300 rpm — meets/exceeds tool speed

stem: An angle grinder is rated at 11,000 rpm. Which wheel rating is safe?

choices.text: Any, if you remove the guard

rationales.CHOICE-3: 11,000 rpm or higher

stem: A wire diameter of 0.035" is approximately how many millimeters (to 0.01)?
Convert 0.9 mm to inches (to 0.001").
A bundle of several extension cords lies coiled in a narrow channel. How to reduce overheating risk?

choices.text: Do nothing — cable will handle it
Separate for airflow, use a single heavier-gauge cord instead of several, and remove coils/reels

rationales.CHOICE-2: Separate for airflow, use a single heavier-gauge cord instead of several, and remove coils/reels

stem: An extension cord on a reel is used at high load. Best way to lower overheating risk:

choices.text: Fully unspool, use only needed length, choose heavier gauge, and periodically check temperature
Cover it with a blanket to block drafts

rationales.CHOICE-2: Fully unspool, use only needed length, choose heavier gauge, and periodically check temperature

stem: Where is it most effective to place GFCI protection when feeding tools via an extension cord?

choices.text: At the source receptacle (or use a cord/box with built-in GFCI) to protect the whole run
GFCI isn’t needed if the cable is thick

rationales.CHOICE-1: At the source receptacle (or use a cord/box with built-in GFCI) to protect the whole run

stem: You need 40 m of reach. You have two thin 20 m cords (AWG14) and one heavy 25 m cord (AWG10). What’s preferable for a welder?

choices.text: Connect the two AWG14 cords — length achieved
Use the AWG10 cord and reposition the power source closer to reduce length
Add another thin cord for redundancy
Increase current to compensate for voltage drop

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use the AWG10 cord and reposition the power source closer to reduce length

stem: Which signs indicate excessive voltage drop due to extension cords/connections?

choices.text: Less spatter means everything is perfect
Cold cables during prolonged high load

rationales.CHOICE-1: Unstable, ‘soft’ arc and hot plugs/receptacles/clamps

stem: How should anti-spatter be used correctly?

choices.text: Apply generously inside the gas diffuser
Lightly on nozzles/fixtures; avoid inside the diffuser and on regulator threads
Spray the welder case for easier cleanup

rationales.CHOICE-2: Lightly on nozzles/fixtures; avoid inside the diffuser and on regulator threads

stem: You need to move a gas cylinder to another area. Which sequence is correct?

choices.text: Leave the regulator on, remove the cap, and roll it on the rim
Remove the regulator, install the protective cap, secure it, and move with a cylinder cart
Carry it horizontally with two people
Pull it by the valve for better control

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove the regulator, install the protective cap, secure it, and move with a cylinder cart

stem: A tool’s line cord insulation is damaged. Your action:

choices.text: Wrap with tape and finish the job
Tag out, remove from service, and send for repair/replacement
Use only with a GFCI — that’s enough
Suspend the cord overhead and continue

rationales.CHOICE-2: Tag out, remove from service, and send for repair/replacement

stem: A ball flowmeter reads erratically; it’s mounted at an angle. What should you do?

choices.text: Mount the tube vertically and readjust the flow
Shut off shielding gas for consistency

rationales.CHOICE-2: Mount the tube vertically and readjust the flow

stem: Portable fume extractor shows low airflow; filter indicator is in the red. What should you do?

choices.text: Ignore it — at least it’s quiet
Stop work, service/replace the filter as specified, verify capture at the working distance
Place a fan near your face

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop work, service/replace the filter as specified, verify capture at the working distance

stem: You need to mount a new wheel on a grinder and start work. Choose the correct sequence:

choices.text: Remove the guard; mount any wheel; run at full speed
Inspect the wheel → ring test → confirm wheel rating ≥ tool rpm → install with guard → start while standing to the side and check for runout
Oil the wheel for a smoother cut → run without a guard
Pick a wheel rated below tool rpm for light work

rationales.CHOICE-2: Inspect the wheel → ring test → confirm wheel rating ≥ tool rpm → install with guard → start while standing to the side and check for runout

stem: Wire ‘birdnesting’ occurs at the feeder. Likely cause and action:

choices.text: Lack of shielding gas — raise the flow
Worn/dirty liner and/or wrong drive roll pressure — replace/clean the liner and adjust the rolls
Lens too dark — change filter shade
Remove the contact tip and weld without it

rationales.CHOICE-2: Worn/dirty liner and/or wrong drive roll pressure — replace/clean the liner and adjust the rolls

stem: Porosity appears during GMAW; the nozzle is visibly clogged with spatter. Best plan:

choices.text: Stop; clean nozzle/diffuser; verify gas type/flow and no leaks; check contact tip/liner; then run a test bead
Switch to a larger wire size

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop; clean nozzle/diffuser; verify gas type/flow and no leaks; check contact tip/liner; then run a test bead

stem: After assembling oxy-fuel equipment, the best set of steps to check for leaks is:

choices.text: Use a small flame — leaks will show quickly
Open valves per procedure, apply leak-detecting/soapy solution to joints, look for bubbles, fix leaks, and re-check
Tighten with a pipe wrench by feel

rationales.CHOICE-2: Open valves per procedure, apply leak-detecting/soapy solution to joints, look for bubbles, fix leaks, and re-check

stem: Arc is unstable with signs of arc blow; the work clamp is on a painted area far from the weld. Your fix:

choices.text: Move the clamp to clean bare metal close to the weld and ensure a solid contact

rationales.CHOICE-2: Move the clamp to clean bare metal close to the weld and ensure a solid contact

stem: A copper cable is terminated on an aluminum bus with a standard copper lug; local overheating is evident. Correct remedy:

choices.text: Apply graphite grease on the joint
Use a bimetallic transition lug/pad and rebuild per instructions; replace damaged parts
Paint the area with high-temp coating

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use a bimetallic transition lug/pad and rebuild per instructions; replace damaged parts

stem: At a bolted splice between welding leads you see oxide/green corrosion and loose hardware. What is correct?

choices.text: Just tighten the bolt without disassembly
De-energize; disassemble; clean contacts; replace washers/bolt if needed; reassemble per spec (flat/lock washers), torque to spec; protect from corrosion; verify under load
Spray with penetrating oil and keep working
Add extra insulation over the corrosion

rationales.CHOICE-2: De-energize; disassemble; clean contacts; replace washers/bolt if needed; reassemble per spec (flat/lock washers), torque to spec; protect from corrosion; verify under load

stem: One cable lug runs much hotter than others and there’s a burning smell. What should your diagnosis focus on?

choices.text: Measure voltage drop under load at that lug and compare to others; verify torque/clean contact; replace parts if needed
Measure only open-circuit voltage; if normal, ignore
Reduce current and paint the area with high-temp paint

rationales.CHOICE-1: Measure voltage drop under load at that lug and compare to others; verify torque/clean contact; replace parts if needed

stem: At power cable lugs you see darkening/melted insulation, scorch marks, and odor. Your actions?

choices.text: Stop, de-energize, tag out; disassemble; clean contact faces to bare metal; replace damaged lugs/cable; reassemble to proper torque; then load-test and check heat/voltage drop
Wrap tightly with tape and retighten without disassembly

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop, de-energize, tag out; disassemble; clean contact faces to bare metal; replace damaged lugs/cable; reassemble to proper torque; then load-test and check heat/voltage drop

stem: The work clamp is getting hot and sparking. Best sequence:

choices.text: Clean to bare metal, reposition close to the weld, ensure firm contact; replace worn clamp; check cable integrity and fasteners
Ignore — this is normal at high current

rationales.CHOICE-2: Clean to bare metal, reposition close to the weld, ensure firm contact; replace worn clamp; check cable integrity and fasteners

stem: A welding fixture was repaired: worn locating pins replaced. What is correct for documentation and control?

choices.text: Record the operation in the traveler/router, update part IDs/serials, obtain hold-point sign-off if required, and check repeatability
Lock the fixture until the next PM without records

rationales.CHOICE-2: Record the operation in the traveler/router, update part IDs/serials, obtain hold-point sign-off if required, and check repeatability

stem: During fixture repair, an engineer proposes adding a stop (design change). Proper approach:

choices.text: Do it immediately; it’s a small tweak
Initiate MOC/ECN/ECR, get approval, update drawing/work instructions, then implement
Make the change now; document after the batch
Let the welder decide on the spot

rationales.CHOICE-2: Initiate MOC/ECN/ECR, get approval, update drawing/work instructions, then implement

stem: After fixture repair, which checks are appropriate before release to production?

choices.text: Calibrate/verify key dimensions, trial assembly/weld a control sample with measurements, verify repeatability; sign off in the traveler
Have a fitter sign for the inspector

rationales.CHOICE-2: Calibrate/verify key dimensions, trial assembly/weld a control sample with measurements, verify repeatability; sign off in the traveler

stem: During fixture repair, clamps were replaced with a different part number. How do you maintain traceability?

choices.text: Record the change in the fixture log/traveler with the new part number/lot; update the fixture list at the cell and train staff if needed
Throw old parts in an unmarked bin

rationales.CHOICE-2: Record the change in the fixture log/traveler with the new part number/lot; update the fixture list at the cell and train staff if needed

stem: What is the correct way to assess voltage drop on a long welding lead?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Compare voltage at the power source vs. at the torch/holder while welding (under load); also monitor cable/connection temperature

stem: What is the correct method to attach lugs to welding cables?

choices.text: To remove moisture that can damage tools and processes

rationales.CHOICE-2: To remove moisture that can damage tools and processes

stem: How should compressed gas cylinders be stored when not in use?

choices.text: Upright and secured with a chain or strap

rationales.CHOICE-2: Upright and secured with a chain or strap

stem: How should oxygen and fuel gas cylinders be stored relative to each other?

stem: What should you do if a power tool’s cord insulation is damaged?

stem: For a long extension cord feeding a welder, which practice is best?

choices.text: Use the smallest gauge to save weight
Use a larger (heavier) gauge to minimize voltage drop

choices.text: Horizontally, so the ball rolls freely

choices.text: It ensures airflow and capture efficiency

rationales.CHOICE-2: It ensures airflow and capture efficiency

choices.text: A metal ladder as a ground

rationales.CHOICE-3: A GFCI-protected supply

choices.text: To maintain gas coverage and reduce porosity

rationales.CHOICE-2: To maintain gas coverage and reduce porosity

Insulation must be intact and jaws clean with no exposed conductors

stem: Between uses, low-hydrogen electrodes (e.g., E7018) should be:

choices.text: Stored open to shop air to cool

stem: Which is correct regarding welder power source ventilation?

Place the machine against a wall to save space

stem: A sign that a GMAW gun liner may need replacement is:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Increased feeding resistance and birdnesting

stem: How should oxy-fuel connections be checked for leaks after assembly?

rationales.CHOICE-3: With a leak-detecting (soapy) solution

stem: What should be avoided around welder cooling fans?

choices.text: Blocking the intake to reduce noise

rationales.CHOICE-2: Blocking the intake to reduce noise

stem: What should be done with a regulator that has a cracked or missing gauge lens?

choices.text: Use it carefully until a replacement arrives

stem: Before mounting a new bonded grinding wheel, which check is recommended?

choices.text: Spin it up on the grinder at full speed

stem: What is an appropriate use of anti-spatter compound?

choices.text: Lightly on nozzles/fixtures per manufacturer’s guidance

rationales.CHOICE-3: Lightly on nozzles/fixtures per manufacturer’s guidance

stem: To ensure a good return path, the work clamp should be attached to:

choices.text: They reduce voltage drop and overheating at the connections

Work at height on a beam is planned. Best pre‑work plan:

Keep the load uphill, low, and tilted back; travel slowly; do not turn on the slope

choices.text: Grease the brake, wrap chain over the hook, then pull

stem: For a JHA/toolbox talk before rigging a plate, which step‑wise plan is best?

choices.text: Rig and pull immediately; discussion wastes time

Identify sharp edges/splinters (gloves, edge pads) → pinch hazards during sling assembly (hands out of pinch plane) → fall zone/swing (tag lines, barriers) → comms with operator/signal person → balance check on trial lift

rationales.CHOICE-2: Identify sharp edges/splinters (gloves, edge pads) → pinch hazards during sling assembly (hands out of pinch plane) → fall zone/swing (tag lines, barriers) → comms with operator/signal person → balance check on trial lift

stem: You encounter a scaffold with a missing/red tag. Proper action:

choices.text: Do not use; barricade/notify; request inspection by a competent person and correct tagging
Add a board and keep working

rationales.CHOICE-2: Do not use; barricade/notify; request inspection by a competent person and correct tagging

stem: A part of unknown weight must be lifted. Choose the best sequence.

choices.text: Go straight to full lift—no time to wait
Verify slings/shackles/angles → set exclusion zone and tag lines → short trial lift a few cm to check balance/brakes → correct as needed → only then proceed

stem: A load on a forklift completely blocks forward view; an aisle intersection is ahead. Choose the correct actions.

choices.text: Drive forward with the load raised to see over it

Treat the lift as a 2‑leg calculation; equalize leg lengths with a master link/spreader; keep angle to horizontal ≥60° (or to vertical ≤30°); protect edges; use tag lines to stabilize; avoid side‑loading the shackle pin
Choke the frame around thin flanges for a ‘better grip’
Lift without tag lines—stabilization is unnecessary

rationales.CHOICE-2: Treat the lift as a 2‑leg calculation; equalize leg lengths with a master link/spreader; keep angle to horizontal ≥60° (or to vertical ≤30°); protect edges; use tag lines to stabilize; avoid side‑loading the shackle pin

stem: A 3‑leg bridle is used, but due to geometry only TWO legs carry the load. Load weight is 2.0 t. Each loaded leg is at 45° from horizontal. What is the tension in one loaded leg? (use T = W/(2·sinθ); round to 0.01 t)
An acceptable anchorage for a fall‑arrest system is typically:

choices.text: An engineered or structural anchorage point

rationales.CHOICE-2: An engineered or structural anchorage point

stem: Which condition requires removing a chain sling from service?

stem: Compared with a basket hitch, a choker hitch of the same sling typically:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Has lower capacity

stem: Which statement about crane hand signals is correct?

Anyone may give the universal emergency stop signal

stem: When traveling with a load on a forklift, you should:

choices.text: Carry the load high for visibility
Carry the load low and tilted back

stem: Before using a chain fall/lever hoist, you should:

choices.text: Check the brake/pawl function with a light test lift
Remove the nameplate to reduce weight

stem: Before using a full‑body harness, you should:

choices.text: Check webbing, stitching, and hardware; remove if damaged
Use any carabiner from the hardware store

rationales.CHOICE-2: Check webbing, stitching, and hardware; remove if damaged

stem: When climbing a ladder, which practice is correct?

choices.text: Lean far to the side to reach
Stand on the top cap for better height

stem: What is the recommended setup angle for a straight ladder?

stem: Which statement about crane operations is correct?

choices.text: It is acceptable to ride the hook for short distances

stem: If rigging gear’s history or condition is unknown, you should:

Remove it from service and have it inspected

stem: On platforms at height, which protection is appropriate?

stem: Before using a scaffold, a best practice is to:

choices.text: Check that it’s tagged/inspected by a competent person

stem: For a two‑leg sling connection using a shackle, a good practice is:

choices.text: Load on the pin with side loading

stem: Why use a shock‑absorbing lanyard in fall arrest?

rationales.CHOICE-2: To reduce forces on the body during a fall

stem: Which statement about stepladders is correct?

stem: You need to dress a part quickly on a bench grinder in a damp area. The safe choice is:

Safety glasses only and no extraction

stem: You are welding stainless steel (GMAW) indoors. The most appropriate primary controls are:

stem: When working with acetylene cylinders, the cylinder valve is typically opened:

choices.text: On the floor near the welder
In a designated stub bucket or container

choices.text: Only to improve the welder’s visibility
To protect others from arc flash and flying sparks

Symmetric tack‑up; skip sequence of short runs; back‑step; alternate sides; use fixturing

Cutting: noise → sunglasses; Assembly: pinch points → remove gloves for feel

stem: A hole Ø0.406" ±0.005" must be documented in mm (round to two decimals). Pick the correct nominal ± tolerance.

stem: At a hold point an out‑of‑tolerance fillet size is found: 7.2 mm vs requirement 8.0 ± 0.5 mm. What is the best course of action?

Stop work, segregate the part, raise an NCR; choose disposition—rework to drawing size, or use‑as‑is ONLY with engineering approval, or scrap; record the decision on the router/traveler before continuing

stem: Stray arc strikes outside weld zone—correct sequence:

stem: Air‑carbon gouging assigned to remove backing/lack of fusion. Best step set:

stem: Temporary backing used; drawing requires REMOVAL. Choose the correct procedure.

stem: Exceeding interpass temperature versus WPS typically results in:

stem: Applying anti‑spatter to jigs/fixtures can:

stem: Maintaining a short arc length generally:

stem: To avoid hard spots and cracking from stray arc strikes, where should arc strikes be made?

stem: If a temporary backing strip is used and drawings require removal, you should:

stem: To maintain a consistent root gap during fit‑up, you should use:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Interpass control manages microstructure and cracking susceptibility.

stem: Peening of weld metal should be used:

choices.text: Heavily on root and final passes
Lightly on intermediate passes only if permitted by code/WPS
As a substitute for proper parameters

rationales.CHOICE-2: Peening can relieve stress but is restricted—avoid on root/final unless allowed.

stem: Changing welding polarity from what the WPS specifies may:

choices.text: Cause lack of fusion or instability

rationales.CHOICE-2: Incorrect polarity can reduce fusion and arc stability.

stem: How should power source polarity be chosen?

choices.text: Use the same polarity for all processes
Follow the WPS and consumable manufacturer requirements

rationales.CHOICE-2: Different processes and wires/rods require specific polarity for proper fusion.

stem: If unexpected porosity appears, a first troubleshooting step is to:

choices.text: Check gas flow/coverage and surface cleanliness

rationales.CHOICE-2: Verify shielding gas and cleanliness before changing parameters.

stem: Why rotate parts on a positioner/turntable when possible?

choices.text: To weld in the flat position for better quality and deposition
To remove the need for fit‑up

rationales.CHOICE-2: Flat‑position welding improves control and productivity.

stem: Before production welding on a new setup, a good approach is to:

choices.text: Run practice beads on scrap of similar material and thickness

rationales.CHOICE-2: Practice beads help dial in parameters and technique.

stem: How should preheat be verified?

choices.text: With temperature‑indicating crayons or a thermometer

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use objective temperature indicators to confirm required preheat.

stem: Excessive preheat beyond WPS requirements may:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Too much preheat can coarsen microstructure and increase distortion.

stem: What is the purpose of a root face (land) on a groove?

choices.text: To help control root penetration and support the root
To eliminate the need for backing

rationales.CHOICE-2: A small land helps control root penetration and bead shape.

stem: Run‑on/run‑off tabs are installed to:

choices.text: Start/stop off the part and achieve full fusion at tie‑ins

rationales.CHOICE-2: Tabs allow full penetration and clean tie‑ins without damaging part edges.

stem: Shielding gas flow for GMAW/GTAW should be set to:

choices.text: The highest possible to be safe
Provide stable coverage without turbulence or aspiration
A fixed value for all nozzles

rationales.CHOICE-2: Set flow to protect the pool; too much flow causes turbulence and air entrainment.

stem: Skip or back‑step welding sequences are used mainly to:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Heat distribution reduces distortion and residual stress.

stem: What should be done between weld passes with flux‑shielded processes?

choices.text: Water‑quench slag to speed the job

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cleaning between passes prevents slag inclusions and improves fusion.

stem: On stainless steel, use a wire brush that is:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Avoid cross‑contamination; use stainless‑only brushes on stainless.

stem: For low‑hydrogen electrodes on many applications, it is preferable to use:

choices.text: Stringer beads or limited weave per WPS

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stringers help control heat input and hydrogen cracking risk.

stem: How should tack welds be placed to control distortion?

choices.text: All tacks on one side of the joint
Balanced around the joint to hold alignment

rationales.CHOICE-2: Balanced, adequate tacks hold fit‑up and reduce distortion during welding.

stem: How should tack welds be prepared for incorporation into the final weld?

choices.text: Feather/clean tacks so they fuse smoothly into the weld

rationales.CHOICE-2: Feathered, clean tacks reduce lack‑of‑fusion at tie‑ins.

stem: Increasing travel speed (all else equal) generally:

choices.text: Lowers heat input and narrows the bead

rationales.CHOICE-2: Higher travel speed reduces heat input and penetration.

stem: When using powered wire brushes, wear:

choices.text: No eye protection; bristles are soft
Safety glasses and a face shield

rationales.CHOICE-2: Wire bristles can eject; use both glasses and a face shield.

stem: You are laying out a square corner using a scaled 3‑4‑5 triangle. If the “4” leg must be 1200 mm, what lengths should you mark for the “3” leg and the diagonal “5”?

rationales.CHOICE-1: Correct: scale the 3:4:5 ratio—3/4×1200=900 mm and 5/4×1200=1500 mm.

stem: A 3‑4‑5 triangle is scaled so the diagonal (“5”) is 2.5 m. What lengths should the “3” and “4” legs be?

rationales.CHOICE-3: 1.6 & 2.4 correspond to a 2.0 m diagonal (not 2.5 m).
rationales.CHOICE-4: 1.8 m would pair with 2.4 m for a 3‑4‑5 at 3.0 m diagonal.

stem: For one 90° bend with inside radius R=4.0 mm, thickness t=2.0 mm, and K=0.33, what is the bend allowance (to 0.01 mm)? Use BA = (π/2) × (R + K·t).

rationales.CHOICE-2: ≈πR (or K=0) error—ignores K·t and angle factor.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Uses π×(R+Kt) (full 180°) instead of 90°.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Sum (R+Kt) without multiplying by π/2.

stem: If you step off ten features in a chain, each ±0.5 mm, what worst‑case cumulative error can the last feature have relative to the first?

rationales.CHOICE-4: Correct: worst‑case stack = 10×0.5 = ±5.0 mm; measure from a datum to avoid this.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Assumes no stacking.
rationales.CHOICE-2: Only two steps of error—understates risk.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Half of the true worst case.

stem: To wrap a square cut line around a pipe of diameter 89.0 mm, what wrap length (circumference) do you need, to the nearest 0.1 mm?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Over‑rounded; acceptable only if coarse tolerance is allowed.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Numerical error—too small for πD.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Confuses circumference with diameter.

stem: Convert 2‑13/16 in to millimeters (two decimals).

rationales.CHOICE-2: Under‑rounded.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Rounded to a whole mm—too coarse.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Over‑estimated.

stem: Convert 1/4 in to millimeters.

rationales.CHOICE-1: Correct: 0.25 in × 25.4 = 6.35 mm.
rationales.CHOICE-2: Rounded down.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Treats 25 mm as 1 in—wrong basis.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Unrelated guess.

stem: Convert 3/8 in to millimeters (to two decimals).

rationales.CHOICE-1: Under‑rounded; drops significant digits.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Over‑rounded upward.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Incorrect conversion.

stem: A metric vernier caliper shows 12.00 mm on the main scale; the 14th vernier line (0.02 mm per division) aligns. What is the reading?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Adds 0.14 mm (0.01 mm/div) — wrong vernier least count.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Adds 0.40 mm—too large.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Digits reversed; not how verniers work.

stem: What is the primary use of an angle finder/protractor in layout?

choices.text: Checking or setting angles against drawings

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: use it to verify/set angles to match the specification.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Not a thickness tool.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Weight requires density/volume calculations, not a protractor.
rationales.CHOICE-4: COG is not found with a protractor.

stem: Why include bend allowance when laying out bent parts?

choices.text: Material does not stretch during bending
To reach the required finished lengths after bending

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: the neutral axis shifts; accounting for BA preserves final dimensions.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Materials stretch/compress in the bend region.
rationales.CHOICE-3: BA does not eliminate springback.
rationales.CHOICE-4: BA uses a K‑factor; it does not replace it.

stem: A combination square can be used to:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: combination squares quickly verify 90°/45° and set offsets.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Not a painting tool.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Amperage is electrical; use a meter.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Spindle speeds are set by machine controls, not a square.

stem: Which practice is correct when choosing a layout datum?

choices.text: Use several random edges as datums
Select one clear datum to control accumulated error
Always measure from part centerlines only

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: a single, repeatable datum reduces variation and stack‑up.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Multiple random datums multiply errors.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Skipping datums leads to inconsistency.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Centerlines are not always defined; use the drawing’s specified datums.

stem: To limit cumulative error across multiple features, you should measure:

choices.text: From changing local edges each time
From the same datum(s) each time

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: re‑referencing the same datum prevents additive ‘chain’ error.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Changing edges creates chain‑dimension error.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Random marks are not datums.
rationales.CHOICE-4: A midpoint is not a general datum unless defined on the drawing.

stem: How can layout lines be kept visible through handling and fitting?

choices.text: Use contrasting markers/soapstone and refresh as needed

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: high‑contrast marks remain visible and can be renewed.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Deep grooves damage parts and invite rework.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Memory is unreliable for precise layout.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Paint obscures reference lines.

stem: Which tools help verify level and plumb during layout/fit‑up?

choices.text: Spirit level, plumb bob, or laser level

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: levels/plumb bobs/lasers check horizontal and vertical alignment.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Micrometers measure thickness/diameter, not level/plumb.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Feeler gauges measure gaps, not level/plumb.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Calipers do not indicate level/plumb.

stem: To avoid losing layout marks during cutting/grinding, you should:

choices.text: Use water to wash them off
Protect or remark them after each step
Rely on the first mark only

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: protect, bridge, or refresh marks to preserve references.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Washing removes useful marks.
rationales.CHOICE-3: One mark won’t survive multiple operations.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Ventilation is unrelated to mark preservation.

stem: What tool helps mark square lines around pipe for cutting?

choices.text: A pipe wrap or flexible square

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: flexible wraps conform to the pipe to mark square circumferential lines.
rationales.CHOICE-1: A magnet base holds tools, it doesn’t wrap or mark.
rationales.CHOICE-3: A punch marks points, not square lines around a pipe.
rationales.CHOICE-4: A drill press is unrelated to layout marking.

stem: A radius gauge is used to:

choices.text: Check concave/convex radii against a template

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: compare edge radii to fixed templates for go/no‑go checks.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Angles are measured with a protractor/angle finder.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Voltage is electrical, not a layout task.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Thickness is measured with calipers/micrometers.

stem: On oiled or scaled steel, which layout method is best?

choices.text: Use a scribe or a contrasting paint marker

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: a hard scribe line or high‑contrast paint mark stays visible on scale/oil.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Graphite marks wipe off easily on oil/scale.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Soapstone/chalk can rub off quickly and lack contrast on heavy scale.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Skipping layout invites fit‑up errors.

stem: For accuracy, a steel rule should be read:

choices.text: By estimating to the nearest centimeter
To the smallest graduation on the rule

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: read to the finest graduation and align the true zero for accuracy.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Centimeter estimation is too coarse.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Always rounding up biases the result.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Reading from a non‑zero edge adds systematic error.

stem: What is the 3‑4‑5 rule used for during layout?

choices.text: Checking 90° squareness by forming a 3‑4‑5 triangle
Finding the center of a circle

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: lengths in a 3‑4‑5 ratio form a right triangle, verifying 90°.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Thickness is measured with calipers or micrometers.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Levels, not 3‑4‑5, are used for leveling.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Circle centers are found by chord/diameter methods, not 3‑4‑5.

stem: Tolerance stack‑up can be reduced by:

choices.text: Measuring from a single datum with a controlled sequence
Scaling from prints instead of using stated dimensions

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: one consistent datum minimizes accumulated error.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Random references create additive error.
rationales.CHOICE-3: Ignoring tolerances does not control stack‑up.
rationales.CHOICE-4: Scaling from prints introduces print scaling error.

stem: Which tool helps transfer equal distances accurately during layout?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct: dividers and combination squares let you repeat and transfer distances precisely.
rationales.CHOICE-1: Chalk is visible but not precise for transferring equal increments.
rationales.CHOICE-3: A finger is not a measuring device and introduces large error.
rationales.CHOICE-4: A pry bar is not a layout/measurement tool.

stem: Balancing welds on opposite sides helps to:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Balanced welding reduces distortion.

stem: Why choose a proper bevel angle during prep?

choices.text: The right angle allows access and proper penetration

rationales.CHOICE-2: Adequate groove angle lets the electrode/torch reach the root and sidewalls.

stem: What are bridge tacks used for?

choices.text: They are forbidden for any process

rationales.CHOICE-1: Bridge tacks hold edges where gaps exist until proper welding occurs.

stem: How do chill bars help when welding thin material?

choices.text: They extract heat to control distortion

rationales.CHOICE-2: Heat sinks pull heat away to limit distortion and burn‑through.

stem: How should distortion be addressed during planning?

choices.text: Plan fit and sequence to allow for predicted shrinkage
Heat input is unrelated to distortion

rationales.CHOICE-2: Anticipating shrinkage enables countermeasures.

stem: Why remove burrs and oxides from prepared edges?

choices.text: It saves time but reduces strength
It is unnecessary on any material
It improves fusion and reduces inclusions

rationales.CHOICE-3: Clean, smooth edges promote full fusion and fewer inclusions.

stem: A fillet-weld gauge is used to measure:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Gauges verify fillet size against requirements.

stem: When should fit‑up be verified?

choices.text: Before welding—check dimensions, gaps, and angles
Skip if the schedule is tight

rationales.CHOICE-2: Verifying fit‑up beforehand prevents defects and rework.

stem: Between passes with flux-shielded processes you should:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cleaning prevents slag inclusions and lack of fusion.

stem: Why mark part orientation before tacking/welding?

choices.text: They are not allowed on steel

rationales.CHOICE-2: Orientation marks help ensure parts are positioned as designed.

stem: Preheating before welding primarily:

choices.text: Reduces cooling rate and hydrogen cracking risk

rationales.CHOICE-2: Preheat slows cooling and lowers crack risk.

stem: Presetting (offsetting) parts opposite expected shrinkage is used to:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Preset enables correct alignment after shrinkage.

stem: A small root face (land) on groove edges helps to:

choices.text: Control root penetration and support the root

rationales.CHOICE-2: A land supports root control and bead shape.

stem: Why install run‑on and run‑off tabs?

choices.text: To achieve full fusion at tie‑ins and protect part edges

rationales.CHOICE-2: Tabs allow starting/ending outside the part for complete fusion.

stem: A symmetric welding sequence on a long seam helps:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Symmetry helps control distortion on long joints.

stem: Why use shims during fit‑up?

choices.text: To ensure a consistent root gap when parts vary

rationales.CHOICE-1: Temporary shims help set uniform gaps before welding.

stem: Why use skip or backstep welding sequences?

choices.text: To concentrate heat in one area
To distribute heat and reduce distortion
To always weld straight through in one pass

rationales.CHOICE-2: Sequencing spreads heat input and limits distortion.

stem: What is the function of strongbacks during fabrication?

choices.text: They prevent distortion and hold alignment while welding

rationales.CHOICE-2: Strongbacks restrain parts to counteract weld shrinkage.

stem: For temporary strongbacks or tabs, a best practice is to:

choices.text: Remove and finish per drawings/WPS after welding

rationales.CHOICE-2: Temporary attachments should be removed and finished as specified.

stem: Before final welding, temporary tacks or dogs that interfere should be:

choices.text: Removed or reshaped per plan to allow proper access

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove interferences so the torch can reach sidewalls/root.

stem: The compressor delivers 5.0 scfm at 90 psi. A 45 A hand plasma cutter requires at least 6.0 scfm at 90 psi. What should you do?

choices.text: Run as is — the cut will just be slower
Turn current down to 20 A and the issue disappears
Provide ≥6.0 scfm (bigger compressor/air line) or run a smaller current and nozzle matched to available flow
Raise pressure to 120 psi with the same compressor

rationales.CHOICE-3: Too little flow causes an unstable arc and premature consumable wear; meet the flow spec or down‑rate to match available air.

stem: The gauge shows 6 bar at idle but drops to 4 bar while cutting. The edge is rough and the arc wanders. What should you check first?

choices.text: Compressor capacity/hose size and any restrictions in the air path
Add a 50 m extension cord — it will help

rationales.CHOICE-2: A pressure drop under load points to inadequate flow or a restrictive/undersized air supply path.

stem: Where is it best to place a moisture/oil separator (dryer) for PAC?

choices.text: Downstream of the compressor, close to the plasma cutter, with regular draining
Upstream of the compressor — that keeps the whole system dry
Not needed; shop air is already ‘dry’
After the torch — on the hose

rationales.CHOICE-1: Place the dryer after the compressor/receiver and as close to the machine as practical for best removal of moisture and oil.

stem: When piercing 12 mm plate, how do you reduce blowback spatter onto the nozzle?

choices.text: Touch the nozzle to the plate and immediately start moving
Raise to 1.5–2× normal standoff and slightly tilt away until the jet breaks through, then level out
Lower the air pressure to the minimum
Pierce on the very edge of the part

rationales.CHOICE-2: Extra height and a slight tilt during the pierce reduce molten blowback onto the nozzle and extend consumable life.

stem: Where should lead‑in/lead‑out be placed when nesting parts for cutting?

choices.text: On the ‘good’ finished edge — it’s more accurate
On scrap, outside the finished contour
No lead‑in at all — start right on the contour

rationales.CHOICE-2: Place lead‑in/out on the scrap side so start/stop defects never land on the finished edge.

stem: Inspection shows a deep pit in the electrode face (hafnium). What should you do?

choices.text: Flip the electrode and use the other end
Keep running until it burns through — there’s life left
Replace the electrode (and nozzle if needed) to prevent double‑arcing and kerf angle

rationales.CHOICE-3: A deep crater indicates wear; continuing risks double‑arcing and degraded cut quality.

stem: After the torch was dropped the swirl ring cracked. How will this defect show up in cutting?

choices.text: The arc becomes brighter and more stable
No effect — that part is cosmetic
Unstable arc, bevelled kerf, accelerated nozzle wear
Severe heating of the work clamp cable

rationales.CHOICE-3: A damaged swirl ring disrupts plasma stabilization — arc shape and edge quality suffer.

stem: You’re getting a pronounced bottom burr in corners and at hole exit. What technique change helps?

choices.text: Speed up through the corner by 30–40%
Slow down 20–30% before corners and at hole exit
Raise current by 10 A only in corners

rationales.CHOICE-2: In corners/exits the jet loses energy; a brief slow‑down keeps the jet trailing under control and reduces dross.

stem: Your machine’s duty cycle is 60% at 40 A. You cut 6 minutes out of 10 and thermal protection tripped. Which statement is correct?

choices.text: This is normal — add pauses or reduce current
Change polarity and the protection will disable
Lubricate the fan — that will help

rationales.CHOICE-1: A 60% duty cycle allows at most 6 minutes on per 10‑minute cycle at rated conditions; add cool‑down time or lower current.

stem: Powered through a 50 m extension cord (1.5 mm²), the unit sags and the arc breaks. Your fix?

choices.text: Use a shorter, larger‑gauge cord or connect closer to the panel
Lower the air pressure to 3 bar

rationales.CHOICE-1: Long/thin power leads cause voltage drop — use a shorter and thicker supply cable.

stem: Where should the work clamp be attached for PAC?

choices.text: On painted surface far away — the sparks will reach
On clean metal as close to the cut as possible
On the table, through rubber pads
On a neighboring part — no difference

rationales.CHOICE-2: A clean, short return path improves arc stability and cut quality.

stem: The arc occasionally ‘doubles’ and the kerf is trapezoidal. What does this suggest?

choices.text: Normal operation — a sign of good speed
Worn nozzle/electrode (ovalized orifice, deep electrode crater)
Work clamp cable is too short

rationales.CHOICE-2: Worn consumables cause double‑arcing and kerf angle (bevel).

stem: How can you recognize optimal PAC speed on mild steel?

choices.text: Heavy bottom dross and horizontal lag lines
Nearly vertical lag lines and a thin, easily removed dross
A heavy top bevel — means it’s ‘cold’
Absolutely no line marks on the edge

rationales.CHOICE-2: At proper speed the lag lines are close to vertical and dross is thin and easy to remove.

stem: You must cut Ø14 mm holes in 10 mm plate. How can you improve hole geometry with a hand PAC?

choices.text: Cut at normal speed — holes are no different
Reduce speed by 30–40% and use a short lead‑in with exit onto scrap

rationales.CHOICE-2: Small holes need a slower speed and careful lead‑in/out to limit taper and burrs.

stem: Cutting expanded/perforated metal causes constant arc outages. What helps?

choices.text: Use a constant pilot‑arc mode (if available)
Lower air pressure to the minimum
Install a larger nozzle without changing current

rationales.CHOICE-1: A constant pilot arc maintains reignition while traversing gaps and cutouts.

stem: Cutting galvanized steel produces heavy fumes. What should you do?

choices.text: Provide effective extraction/water table and respiratory PPE
Add oil to the air — it will reduce dust
Lower air pressure to 2 bar — it will be cleaner

rationales.CHOICE-2: Zinc fumes are hazardous — use local exhaust/water table and appropriate respiratory protection or remove the coating first.

stem: The cutter’s stated air demand is 4.5 scfm. About how many liters per minute is that?
Hand cutting along a straightedge, the edge ‘wanders’ due to inconsistent standoff. What can you use to stabilize height?

choices.text: A drag shield/stand‑off shoe or wheel, or a distance ring on the torch
Press the nozzle firmly onto the plate
Cut faster — the arc will straighten out

rationales.CHOICE-1: A mechanical stand‑off helps hold a constant height during manual cutting, improving cut quality.

stem: Why use dry, clean compressed air for PAC?

choices.text: Wet, oily air extends consumable life
Dry, clean air reduces wear and improves cut quality
Nitrogen is always required instead of air

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture and oil contaminate the plasma stream and damage consumables.

stem: What is the benefit of using dry, clean compressed air for PAC?

choices.text: Better splash lubrication of the torch
Less consumable wear and improved cut quality
No benefit; air quality does not matter
Mandatory nitrogen substitution in all cases

rationales.CHOICE-2: Dry, oil‑free air prevents contamination of the arc and orifices.

stem: Excessive standoff/gap in PAC typically:

choices.text: Increases arc stretch, dross, and bevel
Has no effect on the cut

rationales.CHOICE-2: A long arc increases divergence and heat loss, worsening dross and angle.

stem: A sign PAC consumables need replacement is:

choices.text: Wider kerf, more bevel, unstable arc
No change at all after many hours

rationales.CHOICE-2: Worn nozzle/electrode degrade jet focus and arc stability.

stem: Heavy bottom dross is usually a sign of:

choices.text: Travel speed too slow or too low amperage

rationales.CHOICE-1: Too slow or too cold allows molten metal to solidify along the bottom edge.

stem: Heavy bottom dross is usually a sign of what?

choices.text: Too slow a travel speed or insufficient current

rationales.CHOICE-1: Slow/cold cuts leave adherent bottom dross.

stem: Due to kerf angle in PAC, a good practice is to place the 'good side' of the cut:

choices.text: On the workpiece side that must meet size/tolerance

rationales.CHOICE-2: PAC kerf is not perfectly square; orient the torch so the true edge is on the kept side.

stem: Prominent lag lines trailing far behind the torch usually indicate:

rationales.CHOICE-2: If the jet lags too far, travel is too fast for full penetration.

stem: A good practice for piercing with PAC is to:

choices.text: Start right on the plate surface to reduce blowback
Pierce at elevated height/angle to avoid blowback into the nozzle
Always pierce from the edge only
Lower amperage to minimum and drag the tip

rationales.CHOICE-2: Piercing higher/angled directs molten ejecta away from the orifices.

stem: What is the advantage of pilot-arc or HF start in PAC?

choices.text: No need for a power source
Reliable arc initiation without contacting the work
Eliminates the need for air supply
Allows cutting of any non‑conductive materials

rationales.CHOICE-2: Pilot/HF start lights the arc without tip contact, reducing wear.

stem: Which polarity is typical for air plasma cutting systems?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Air plasma torches commonly use DCEN (electrode negative).

stem: How should torch standoff be managed in plasma arc cutting (PAC)?

choices.text: Always drag the tip regardless of torch design
Maintain the proper standoff/drag per the torch to protect consumables

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct standoff prevents nozzle damage and preserves cut quality.

stem: You need to back‑gouge a 10 mm root on carbon steel with CAC‑A. Which carbon and current range is the most appropriate?

choices.text: Ø6 mm (1/4 in) carbon at 150–250 A
Ø8 mm (5/16 in) carbon at 200–350 A
Ø10 mm (3/8 in) carbon at 300–450 A
Ø13 mm (1/2 in) carbon at 550–700 A

rationales.CHOICE-3: A 3/8 in carbon and ~300–450 A gives a controllable, ~10–12 mm wide gouge suitable for a 10 mm root.

stem: Polarity for DC CAC‑A with copper‑coated carbons is typically:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Standard DC CAC‑A uses DCEP for stable arc and proper carbon consumption.

stem: Air pressure measured at the torch during gouging with Ø10 mm (3/8 in) carbon should be about:

rationales.CHOICE-3: Most torches and 3/8 in carbons perform well with ~90–110 psi dynamic pressure at the torch.

stem: When starting the gouge, what sequence helps avoid carbon smearing and blowback?

choices.text: Strike arc first, then open air
Open air fully, then strike and move immediately
Start without air for 20 s to warm the carbon
Feather the air on/off repeatedly while stationary

rationales.CHOICE-2: Having air on before the strike clears molten metal immediately and reduces carbon deposits in the groove.

stem: Typical torch/work angle for a controlled back‑gouge is:

rationales.CHOICE-2: A 15–30° drag angle gives directional control and helps the air jet lift molten metal.

stem: You observe carbon streaks left in the gouged groove on stainless. What’s the correct action before welding?

choices.text: Weld over them; they’ll burn out
Grind/clean to bright metal and re‑gouge lightly if needed
Brush with carbon steel wire only
Spray water to cool and weld immediately

rationales.CHOICE-2: Carbon contamination must be removed on stainless to avoid embrittlement/porosity—grind to bright metal.

stem: Your compressor delivers 35 scfm at 100 psi. The torch spec for 1/2 in carbon needs ~50–60 scfm. What’s the practical solution?

choices.text: Use 1/2 in carbon anyway at reduced current
Manifold more compressor capacity or step down to a smaller carbon
Increase pressure to 150 psi with the same compressor
Reduce air hose ID to boost velocity

rationales.CHOICE-2: Air volume limits carbon size; add air capacity or choose a smaller carbon to match available flow.

stem: Which power source is preferred for CAC‑A?

choices.text: Constant current (CC) DC welder with high duty cycle

rationales.CHOICE-2: CAC‑A requires a robust CC/DC source with ample current and duty cycle.

stem: When feathering the end of a gouge to avoid a crater, the correct move is to:

choices.text: Lift to increase arc length and reduce current
Lower the torch and close the air
Turn off power first, then air

rationales.CHOICE-1: Slightly increasing arc length while moving off reduces depth gradually and prevents a sharp crater.

stem: You must remove a crack stop‑hole without undercutting base metal. Best technique:

choices.text: Start inside the hole, tight circle, shallow passes
Single deep pass across the hole
Strike beside the hole and ‘punch’ through vertically

rationales.CHOICE-1: Controlled, shallow circular feathering avoids sudden undercut and keeps geometry accurate.

stem: A common cause of ‘spitting’ and poor metal ejection during gouging is:

choices.text: Air filter/moisture separator missing or saturated

rationales.CHOICE-1: Moisture/oil in the air stream destabilizes the arc and ejection; keep air dry and filtered.

stem: Which PPE addition is most critical for CAC‑A compared to typical welding?

rationales.CHOICE-1: Noise levels can exceed 100 dBA; hearing protection is essential along with face/eye and fume control.

stem: Back‑gouging a root on a double‑V joint, where should you place the work (return) lead to minimize arc blow?

choices.text: Directly behind the arc on the same member
Far away on a different structure

rationales.CHOICE-1: Short current paths close to the gouge help reduce magnetic arc blow and stabilize the arc.

stem: You need a narrow, shallow gouge for cap removal without damaging the toe. Which adjustment helps most?

choices.text: Use a smaller carbon and reduce current
Increase carbon size but move faster
Use the same carbon and increase air pressure only

rationales.CHOICE-1: Smaller diameter and lower current give finer control and shallower penetration.

stem: During a long pass your torch gets hot and the carbon holder O‑rings show damage. Best immediate action:

choices.text: Stop, cool down, inspect/replace O‑rings, and verify air flow path
Wrap with tape and finish the job

rationales.CHOICE-2: Damaged seals affect air jet direction and safety; correct the fault before proceeding.

stem: For AC gouging you should use:

choices.text: Special AC‑coated carbons designed for AC

rationales.CHOICE-2: AC requires carbons with a special coating to stabilize the arc; DC carbons are for DCEP.

stem: You’re gouging in a corner joint and ejecta keeps bouncing back into the groove. What change helps most?

choices.text: Increase drag angle and redirect the air jet out of the corner
Reduce air pressure to lessen blowout
Shorten the arc length to zero

rationales.CHOICE-1: Adjusting angle directs the stream away from the corner so molten metal can escape.

stem: Which hose setup is most suitable for CAC‑A with high air demand?

choices.text: Long 1/4 in ID air hose with quick‑connects
Short 3/8–1/2 in ID air hose with full‑flow fittings
Any size—length and fittings don’t matter

rationales.CHOICE-2: Large‑ID, short runs and full‑flow fittings minimize pressure drop and keep volume up.

stem: You must back‑gouge inside a tank. What must be in place before starting?

choices.text: Confined‑space entry, ventilation, gas testing, and a hot‑work permit
Only a fan blowing air in

rationales.CHOICE-2: CAC‑A in confined spaces requires formal controls: permit, atmospheric testing, ventilation, standby, etc.

stem: While removing a fillet weld, you keep digging into the base plate near the toe. What technique change helps?

choices.text: Flatten the angle and move faster with lighter, overlapping passes
Hold vertical and pulse the air
Switch to a bigger carbon for stability

rationales.CHOICE-1: A shallower angle with quicker, light passes reduces bite‑in and lets you ‘skim’ the weld metal off.

stem: If CAC-A must be performed on AC, you should use:

choices.text: AC-rated gouging electrodes designed for AC

rationales.CHOICE-2: Special AC-rated carbons are required for stable AC gouging.

stem: What air supply is required for CAC-A?

choices.text: High-volume, dry air to blow molten metal clear

rationales.CHOICE-2: A high-volume stream of dry compressed air clears molten metal.

stem: What is a typical electrode angle for CAC‑A?

choices.text: Lead the electrode 15–20° in the travel direction

rationales.CHOICE-2: A small lead angle directs the molten metal out of the gouge.

stem: Which polarity is standard for air carbon arc gouging (CAC‑A) with DC?

rationales.CHOICE-2: DCEP helps blow molten metal out of the groove effectively.

stem: Which PPE is most appropriate for CAC‑A?

choices.text: Heavy PPE: face shield, hearing protection, leathers

rationales.CHOICE-2: CAC‑A is loud and ejects hot metal; robust PPE is required.

stem: Before changing a wheel on a grinder, you should:

choices.text: Leave it plugged in and use the trigger lock
Disconnect power (unplug/remove battery) and lock the spindle before loosening
Hold the wheel by hand while spinning to loosen
Tap the nut with a hammer to break it free

rationales.CHOICE-2: Isolate energy and use the proper spindle lock/wrench to change accessories safely.

stem: Best practice for stabilizing small workpieces during handheld grinding is to:

choices.text: Clamp the work in a vise/jig before grinding
Balance them on your knee for control

rationales.CHOICE-2: Secure clamping prevents loss of control, kickback, and injury.

stem: Which practice is correct for cut‑off wheels on handheld grinders?

choices.text: Side‑grind with heavy pressure to speed the cut
Use only radial loads; do not side‑grind with cut‑off wheels
Remove the guard for better visibility
Lubricate the wheel with oil while cutting

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cut‑off wheels are not designed for side loading and can shatter if side‑ground.

stem: A bench grinder wheel shows glazing and burn marks during use. What is the correct action?

choices.text: Increase pressure to force material removal
Dress the wheel to expose fresh abrasive and true the face
Quench the wheel in water while it spins
Sand the wheel face with sandpaper

rationales.CHOICE-2: Dressing removes glazing, restores cutting ability, and trues the wheel.

stem: Which statement about mounting flanges and blotters is correct?

choices.text: Mismatched, small flanges increase pressure and are preferred
Use matched flanges with blotter labels per manufacturer instructions
Blotters are optional on vitrified wheels
Any washer can substitute for a flange

rationales.CHOICE-2: Proper, matched flanges and blotters distribute clamping forces and protect the wheel.

stem: When using a handheld grinder, how should the guard be positioned relative to the operator?

choices.text: Between the wheel and the operator to deflect debris away
Aimed to direct sparks toward coworkers

rationales.CHOICE-2: The guard should block fragments and direct sparks away from the operator and others.

stem: During a cut with a thin cut‑off wheel, the kerf closes and the wheel binds. What is the safest immediate response?

choices.text: Twist the grinder to free the wheel
Release the trigger, keep the tool aligned, and wait for the wheel to stop
Push harder to force the cut through
Open the guard to relieve pressure

rationales.CHOICE-2: Let the wheel stop under control; twisting or forcing increases kickback and fracture risk.

stem: Before mounting a vitrified grinding wheel, what check should be performed?

choices.text: Spin it at full speed on the grinder first
Perform a ring test and visually inspect for cracks
Soak it in oil for lubrication
Strike it hard with a steel hammer

rationales.CHOICE-2: A ring (sound) test plus visual inspection helps detect hidden cracks before use.

stem: You must grind near stored combustibles. Which control is appropriate?

choices.text: Use spark shields/curtains and aim sparks away from combustibles
Turn off local exhaust to avoid pulling sparks

rationales.CHOICE-2: Shield and redirect sparks away from combustibles; maintain ventilation if required.

stem: How should resin‑bonded abrasive wheels be stored?

choices.text: In damp areas to keep cool
Dry, flat, and protected from impact

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture and impacts degrade resin‑bonded wheels; store them dry, flat, and supported.

stem: In a tight corner, the guard blocks access for your grinder. What is the correct approach?

choices.text: Remove the guard and proceed carefully
Use a smaller tool/wheel or a different process that fits with the guard in place
Hold the grinder at 90° to bypass the guard
Loosen the guard so it hangs out of the way

rationales.CHOICE-2: Never defeat guards; select tooling/process that allows guarded operation.

stem: After dressing a bench grinder wheel, what is the recommended maximum gap between the wheel and the top tongue guard (spark arrestor)?

choices.text: Zero — guard must touch the wheel

rationales.CHOICE-1: Keep the tongue guard close (≈6 mm) to limit debris ejection as the wheel wears.

stem: On a bench grinder, what is the correct tool rest clearance to the wheel?

rationales.CHOICE-1: A small ~3 mm (1/8 in) gap reduces the chance of the workpiece jamming the wheel.

stem: Your angle grinder is rated at 11,000 rpm (no‑load). Which wheel rating is acceptable?

rationales.CHOICE-2: A wheel’s maximum rpm must meet or exceed the grinder’s rated speed.

stem: What eye/face protection is appropriate when using a powered wire wheel?

choices.text: Safety glasses and a face shield
No eye protection for quick jobs

rationales.CHOICE-2: Wire bristles can eject at high energy; use both safety glasses and a face shield.

stem: Why are paper blotters used between grinding wheel flanges and the wheel?

choices.text: They distribute clamping force and protect the wheel

rationales.CHOICE-2: Blotters cushion and spread load to reduce stress concentrations.

stem: What is the safe use rule for cut‑off wheels?

choices.text: Side‑grind with heavy pressure for speed
Do not side‑grind with cut‑off wheels
It is fine with the guard removed

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cut‑off wheels are not designed for side loads and can shatter.

stem: Dressing a grinding wheel primarily:

choices.text: Restores shape and exposes sharp abrasive

rationales.CHOICE-2: Dressing trues the wheel and renews cutting action.

stem: How should a grinder guard be positioned?

choices.text: Place the guard between the wheel and the operator

rationales.CHOICE-2: The guard should block fragments and direct debris away from the user.

stem: Before mounting a bonded grinding wheel, a recommended check is to:

choices.text: Spin it up on the grinder first
Perform a ring test and inspect for cracks
Strike it with a hammer forcefully

rationales.CHOICE-2: A ring (sound) test helps detect hidden cracks.

stem: How should wheel RPM ratings relate to tool RPM?

choices.text: Wheel rating may be below tool speed
Wheel rating must meet or exceed the tool’s maximum RPM
Any mismatch is fine for brief use

rationales.CHOICE-2: A wheel must be rated for at least the tool’s maximum rotational speed.

stem: A quick spark test during grinding can help to:

choices.text: Identify general steel type by spark pattern

rationales.CHOICE-2: Spark patterns give a rough indication of carbon/alloy content.

stem: On a bench grinder, the tool rest should be kept:

choices.text: As far from the wheel as possible
As close as practical (about 3 mm / 1⁄8 in) from the wheel

rationales.CHOICE-2: Small clearance reduces the chance of workpiece jamming.

stem: How should bonded abrasive wheels be stored?

choices.text: In a damp area to keep cool
Dry, flat, and protected from dropping

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture and impacts damage wheels; keep them dry and supported.

stem: What PPE is appropriate when using a powered wire wheel?

choices.text: No eye protection; bristles are soft
Safety glasses and a face shield

rationales.CHOICE-2: Wire bristles can eject; use both glasses and a shield.

stem: What’s the correct way to leak‑test oxy‑fuel connections?

choices.text: Use an open flame — it’s faster
Apply a soapy solution/leak detector and watch for bubbles

rationales.CHOICE-3: A soapy solution safely shows micro‑bubbling; open‑flame checks or ‘listening only’ are unacceptable.

stem: Lighting sequence for a hand torch:

choices.text: Open oxygen, ignite, then add acetylene
Open both gases fully and ignite
Crack acetylene at the torch, ignite, then add oxygen to a neutral flame
Ignite the work first, then bring in the torch

rationales.CHOICE-3: Start with a small fuel flow, then add oxygen to set a neutral flame.

stem: A safe full shutdown after work includes:

choices.text: Close only the torch valves — leave regulators alone
Close cylinder valves, bleed lines through the torch, back out regulator screws to zero
Leave pressure in hoses — faster next day
Vent through the regulator, keep cylinders open

rationales.CHOICE-2: Shut cylinders, depressurize lines, and release regulator spring load to reduce risk and wear.

stem: Proper cylinder position for use/storage:

choices.text: On a hand truck at an angle, unrestrained
Any position if the cap is on

rationales.CHOICE-2: Keep cylinders vertical and secured to prevent tipping and acetone carryover (acetylene).

stem: Acetylene 1/7 rule: from a T cylinder (~300 ft³) you may withdraw no more than…

rationales.CHOICE-2: 1/7 of 300 ft³ ≈ 42.9 CFH; higher rates pull acetone and destabilize the flame.

stem: Convert 50 CFH to L/min:
A rosebud needs 25 L/min of acetylene. How many CFH is that?
Your rosebud needs 80 CFH acetylene and you have a single T cylinder. What’s the safe option?

choices.text: Open acetylene fully — the regulator will hold it
Lower oxygen pressure and carry on
Use a cylinder manifold or switch to an alternative fuel
Periodically flip the cylinder to ‘add liquid’

rationales.CHOICE-3: 80 CFH exceeds the 1/7 rule for one cylinder; solution: manifold cylinders or another fuel.

stem: Where are reverse‑flow checks and flashback arrestors installed?

choices.text: Oxygen side only, at the regulator
Check valves at the torch; flashback arrestors on both gas lines at the regulator and/or torch
Fuel side only, at the torch
Not needed with a neutral flame

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use check valves and arrestors on both lines to prevent reverse flow and stop flame propagation.

stem: Difference between a check valve and a flashback arrestor:

choices.text: Check valve prevents reverse gas flow; arrestor stops a flame front
A check valve extinguishes flames; an arrestor doesn’t

rationales.CHOICE-2: Different functions: reverse‑flow prevention vs flame stopping.

stem: Signs of a flashback (squeal, body heating). First actions:

choices.text: Continue until it stops on its own
Shut torch valves immediately, close cylinders, let it cool, inspect arrestors/tip
Dip the torch in water and continue

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop gas flow fast, cool down, and inspect to minimize damage and hose fire risk.

stem: When and how should hoses be purged after installing regulators?

choices.text: Open each gas at the torch briefly and separately in a ventilated area away from ignition sources
Open both gases together — faster purge
Purge through the tip with the flame lit

rationales.CHOICE-2: Brief separate purges remove air/moisture without mixing gases.

stem: How far do you open an acetylene cylinder valve in use?

choices.text: About 1/2–3/4 turn (not more than one turn)

rationales.CHOICE-2: A small opening allows quick shutoff in an emergency.

stem: How should you open an oxygen cylinder valve?

choices.text: Quickly to half a turn — that’s enough
Don’t open — the regulator will pull it open

rationales.CHOICE-2: Open slowly and fully for proper valve function and stable flow.

stem: What to do with regulator adjusting screws at full shutdown?

choices.text: Leave them at working pressure to keep settings
Back them out to zero to remove spring/diaphragm load

rationales.CHOICE-2: Releasing the screw prevents spring ‘set’ and extends regulator life.

stem: Why shouldn’t high‑purity copper parts/tubing be used with acetylene?

choices.text: It’s just a recommendation, not a hazard

rationales.CHOICE-2: Some non‑ferrous metals form unstable acetylides with acetylene — impact‑sensitive and hazardous.

stem: Safe way to move gas cylinders in the shop:

choices.text: Roll them on the floor horizontally
Lift with a magnetic crane by the shell
Use a proper cart with a chain and the cap on
‘Walk’ them on the edge while bracing with your foot

rationales.CHOICE-3: Use a cart/chain and a protective cap — prevents tipping and valve impact.

stem: Before cutting a closed vessel/confined space you should:

choices.text: Fill with oxygen to burn off vapors
Crack a lid slightly and cut
Clean/ventilate, perform gas testing, and obtain a hot‑work permit
Pour in some water — that’s enough

rationales.CHOICE-3: Confined‑space cutting requires prep: remove vapors, verify atmosphere, and get authorization.

stem: Most likely cause of a backfire during cutting:

choices.text: Tip touches metal/slag or passages are clogged

rationales.CHOICE-2: Contact and clogging cause local overheating/reverse wave — a typical backfire cause.

stem: Use PTFE (Teflon) tape on the regulator‑to‑cylinder connection?

choices.text: No; CGA connections seal metal‑to‑metal/with a gasket — tape isn’t used
Only if there’s a leak — wrap more

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cylinder‑to‑regulator joints seal on the seating surfaces; tape is for specified pipe threads further downstream.

stem: Typical torch orientation for straight cutting on thick plate:

choices.text: A small 10–20° lead angle in the direction of travel
At 45° away from you to blow slag off
Nozzle pointing backward — easier to hold

rationales.CHOICE-2: A slight lead angle improves slag removal and stream stability on thick sections.

stem: During a shutdown check (cylinders still open), the oxygen delivery gauge creeps from 30 psi to 45 psi with the torch valves closed. What should you do?

choices.text: Bleed the lines, back out the screw, and keep working
Crack the tip valves slightly to relieve pressure
Tag out the regulator and replace/repair it (pressure creep = faulty seat)
Turn the high‑pressure gauge needle back to zero

rationales.CHOICE-3: Pressure creep indicates a leaking HP seat; remove the regulator from service.

stem: While using a square‑stem acetylene cylinder, where should the valve key be during operation?

choices.text: Left on the valve stem for quick shutoff
Not needed once pressures are set

rationales.CHOICE-2: Keeping the key on the valve allows immediate shutdown in an emergency.

stem: You switch to propane for heating. Which hose grade should you use?

rationales.CHOICE-3: T‑grade hoses are required for alternate fuels (propane, natural gas); R/RM are for acetylene only.

stem: What is the safe way to light an oxy‑fuel torch?

choices.text: By touching the tip to hot steel

rationales.CHOICE-3: Use a striker to keep hands away from the tip and avoid open‑flame ignition sources.

stem: Before attaching an oxygen regulator, how should you crack the cylinder valve?

choices.text: Stand in front of the outlet and crack toward you
Stand to the side; point the outlet away from people/equipment; brief crack to blow out debris
Open the valve fully for several seconds
Wrap the outlet with a rag and crack the valve

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stand to the side and direct the outlet away while cracking briefly to clear the seat.

stem: The cutting‑oxygen lever on the torch sticks. What’s the correct action?

choices.text: Oil the lever pivot to free it up
Increase oxygen pressure to overcome the sticking
Remove the torch from service and have it cleaned/repaired—do not lubricate
Tap the lever gently with a hammer

rationales.CHOICE-3: Sticking controls require service; oil/grease is unsafe on oxygen equipment.

stem: How should hoses be routed in a busy shop to avoid damage and trips?

choices.text: Under plates or through pinch points—protected by weight
Elevated or guarded (covers/bridges), kept away from sparks and hot slag
Tied tightly together near the tip

rationales.CHOICE-2: Guard or elevate hoses and keep them out of traffic and hot‑work fallout.

stem: For oxy‑acetylene brazing on clean steel, which flame is preferred?

rationales.CHOICE-3: A slight reducing flame helps protect the molten filler from oxidation.

stem: You switch from acetylene to propane for cutting. What is required?

choices.text: No changes—use the same tip and hoses
Use the manufacturer’s propane‑specific tip/mixer and T‑grade hoses
Add a light oil to the hoses to prevent drying

rationales.CHOICE-2: Alternate fuels need proper tip/mixer design and T‑grade hoses.

stem: Convert 12 L/min to CFH.
After several backfires the tip is very hot and discolored. What should you do before continuing?

choices.text: Dip the tip in water to cool it quickly
Air‑cool, shut off gases, then inspect/clean or replace the tip and seats
Spray a light oil on the tip

rationales.CHOICE-2: Let it cool naturally and restore tip/orifice condition before resuming.

stem: Which sequence is correct for changing an oxygen cylinder?

choices.text: Bleed the low‑pressure side first, then close the cylinder
Close cylinder valve → open torch valve to bleed → back out regulator screw → remove regulator
Remove the regulator while the line is still pressurized
Leave the regulator screw tight to save the setting

rationales.CHOICE-2: Depressurize the system before removing the regulator; then reset the screw.

stem: Which material cannot be cut by the standard oxy‑fuel oxidation process?

rationales.CHOICE-3: Stainless doesn’t support rapid iron‑oxide formation; use plasma or special methods.

stem: You suspect a small system leak. Which simple leak‑down check is valid?

choices.text: Close cylinder valves, note delivery pressure, close torch valves, and observe if pressure holds for several minutes
Open both gases and listen for a hiss
Tap the gauge glass and see if the needle jumps

rationales.CHOICE-1: Stable delivery pressure with cylinders shut indicates no internal leak; a drop suggests leakage.

stem: When piercing 25 mm plate, you get heavy blowback that splashes the tip. What adjustment helps most?

choices.text: Move the tip closer and open the oxygen jet immediately
Increase preheat time and use a slight tip tilt away before opening the oxygen jet
Lower oxygen pressure far below tip chart values
Open the oxygen jet fully from the start at maximum standoff

rationales.CHOICE-2: Thorough preheat and a small lead angle reduce blowback and tip damage.

stem: Where is PTFE (Teflon) tape permissible in an oxy‑fuel setup?

choices.text: Only on specified tapered pipe threads downstream if permitted by the manufacturer
On all metal‑to‑metal seats to help sealing

rationales.CHOICE-3: Use tape only on designated NPT‑type joints downstream; never on CGA/B‑size seats.

stem: You must cut near combustibles. What control is most appropriate?

choices.text: Spray the area with water once at the start
Assign a trained fire watch with proper extinguishers and maintain watch per the hot‑work permit
No action needed with a neutral flame

rationales.CHOICE-2: Fire watch and permit controls mitigate ignition hazards around combustibles.

stem: A coworker uses oxygen to blow dust off clothing. What’s the correct response?

choices.text: Stop it—oxygen can saturate clothing and greatly increase fire risk

rationales.CHOICE-3: Never use oxygen for personal cleaning; it creates an extreme fire hazard.

stem: Cutting 10 mm plate from 25 mm standoff gives a ragged kerf and heavy bottom slag. What change will most likely clean the cut?

choices.text: Increase standoff to keep heat off the plate
Reduce standoff to the recommended tip distance and adjust travel to keep a steady preheat
Throttle the oxygen jet part‑way closed

rationales.CHOICE-2: Proper standoff and steady preheat stabilize the jet and reduce slag.

stem: What is the maximum recommended working pressure for acetylene?

choices.text: Do not use acetylene above 15 psi (≈103 kPa)
Any pressure is acceptable if flashback arrestors are installed

rationales.CHOICE-2: Acetylene becomes unstable at about 15 psi; working pressure is kept below this level.

stem: Why briefly crack a cylinder valve before attaching the regulator?

choices.text: To vent gas for no reason
To blow dust/debris off the outlet seat

rationales.CHOICE-2: A short crack removes contaminants that could damage the regulator.

stem: How do you correctly distinguish a backfire from a flashback?

choices.text: Backfire is when the flame runs into the hoses
Flashback is sustained burning into the torch/hose; backfire is a brief ‘pop’ at the tip

rationales.CHOICE-2: A backfire is a short pop at the tip; a flashback is sustained internal burning and a serious hazard.

stem: Which statement about oxy‑fuel hose/fitting threads is correct?

choices.text: Fuel‑gas fittings use left‑hand threads (often notched); oxygen uses right‑hand threads

rationales.CHOICE-2: Left‑hand threads on fuel lines help prevent cross‑connection with oxygen.

stem: Which description matches a neutral oxy‑fuel flame?

choices.text: A balanced inner cone with no feather
An oxidizing feather on the inner cone

rationales.CHOICE-2: A neutral flame has a distinct inner cone without an acetylene feather.

stem: How should oxygen equipment be handled?

choices.text: Never use oil/grease on oxygen equipment
Always fully backseat the acetylene valve
Do not crack the valve before installing the regulator

rationales.CHOICE-2: Oil and grease can ignite in pure oxygen service.

stem: Which plate‑piercing technique for oxy‑fuel cutting is correct?

choices.text: Lay the tip flat and immediately open full oxygen jet
Tilt the tip, preheat, then open the oxygen jet to pierce
Always start only from an edge
Hold the tip strictly vertical with no preheat

rationales.CHOICE-2: Preheating with a slight tilt reduces blowback of slag and tip damage risk.

stem: Insufficient preheat during cutting often leads to:

choices.text: A narrow kerf and perfect straightness

rationales.CHOICE-2: Too little preheat impairs ignition and jet formation, increasing slag.

stem: Why clean cutting tips with proper cleaners/gauges?

choices.text: To enlarge the orifices for higher flow
To maintain correct orifice size/shape and cut quality

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct cleaners preserve orifice geometry for a stable flame pattern.

stem: If travel speed during cutting is too high, the cut will be:

choices.text: With lag lines leaning far backward (drag)

rationales.CHOICE-2: Excessive speed increases jet lag; too slow tends to produce heavy bottom slag.

stem: What safe starting current should you choose for E7018 Ø3.2 mm (1/8 in) in the flat position on an 8 mm fillet weld?

rationales.CHOICE-2: For 1/8 in E7018 a typical range is ~90–130 A; start mid‑range and adjust by puddle response.

stem: Open‑root butt with ~3 mm gap. What starting current for E6010 Ø3.2 mm (DCEP)?

rationales.CHOICE-2: For 1/8 in E6010, 80–110 A is typical — controllable keyhole without burn‑through.

stem: How should you finish a bead to avoid a crater crack?

choices.text: Snap the arc off sharply at the end
Raise current and ‘shoot’ out of the crater
Fill the crater with a short backstep/small circle, then break the arc smoothly
Extinguish the arc on the base metal

rationales.CHOICE-3: Filling the crater before breaking the arc prevents a shrinkage crack at the bead end.

stem: Before welding through tack welds, what should you do to them?

choices.text: Nothing — the slag will burn out
Grind the tacks flush and feather their edges
Increase current and burn straight through the tacks
Leave as is — it will strengthen the weld

rationales.CHOICE-2: Flush‑grinding and feathering prevent slag entrapment and give a smooth tie‑in for the main pass.

stem: Vertical‑up (3F) T‑joint 10 mm with E7018. Which travel pattern is preferred?

choices.text: Small ‘triangle’/‘Christmas tree’ with brief pauses at the toes

rationales.CHOICE-2: A small triangle with toe pauses holds the puddle and builds even shelves.

stem: On a vertical E7018 weld you get undercut on the upper toe. First corrective action?

choices.text: Slightly reduce current, shorten the arc, and pause at the upper toe

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short arc, a brief toe pause, and moderate current reduce undercut on the top edge.

stem: Overhead (4F/4G) with E7018. What helps hold the puddle?

choices.text: Raise current and use a wide weave
Use a smaller diameter, keep a short arc, and run short stringers
Hold a long arc so it ‘cools’

rationales.CHOICE-2: Smaller diameter, short arc, and short passes minimize dripping and sag in overhead.

stem: WPS limits interpass temperature to ≤200 °C. How do you correctly monitor it on the part?

choices.text: Temperature crayon/contact thermometer on base metal 25–50 mm from the weld toe
Measure on the slag immediately after the pass
Aim a pyrometer at a shiny face with no emissivity correction

rationales.CHOICE-2: Measure the base metal near the weld; slag/‘touch’ checks are unreliable.

stem: A box of E7018 sat outside the rod oven for 5 hours at ~20 °C. What should you do?

choices.text: Warm the tip with a flame and weld
Return the batch for rebake/storage per manufacturer; scrap/rebake any suspect electrodes
Coat with oil to ‘seal’ moisture out

rationales.CHOICE-3: Low‑hydrogen rods have limited ‘open‑time’; if exceeded, rebake per data sheet or replace.

stem: Typical E7018 rebake (after moisture pickup) and subsequent holding regime:

choices.text: 80–100 °C for 10 min; store at room temperature

rationales.CHOICE-3: Rule of thumb: rebake around 315 °C, then hold 120–150 °C; follow the brand/WPS specifics.

stem: Butt joint, 25 mm carbon steel shows cold (hydrogen) cracking. Practical fix:

choices.text: Add preheat ~100–150 °C and control interpass temperature per WPS
Gap to 10 mm and weld with no preheat

rationales.CHOICE-2: Preheat reduces cooling rate and crack risk; control interpass per WPS.

stem: After an E6010 root, a E7018 ‘hot pass’ is planned. What must be done first?

choices.text: Nothing — the slag will float out
Remove all slag/scale to bright metal and verify root fusion
Raise E7018 current and melt the slag out
Spray a chlorinated solvent for cleaning

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cellulosic slag residues cause lack of fusion and ‘wagon tracks’; clean fully before the hot pass.

stem: A 1.2 m fillet on thin section is warping badly. How can you reduce distortion?

choices.text: Use short stitch welds with backstep/symmetric sequence
Max out current and travel speed

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short stitches and backstep/symmetry spread heat input and limit distortion.

stem: Where should the work (return) clamp be attached for SMAW?

choices.text: To a bearing housing near the weld
To an oxygen cylinder — the path is short
To the workpiece as close as practicable to the weld area
To a building steel column for convenience

rationales.CHOICE-3: Clamp to the work near the weld, avoiding current paths through bearings/cylinders/structures.

stem: Sheet 3 mm with E6013: how to avoid burn‑through on a fillet?

choices.text: Use 4.0 mm electrode and high current
