Use 2.5 mm electrode, low‑end current, short arc, and short ‘pecking’ stringers
Hold a long arc and go slow
Make a very wide weave to spread heat

rationales.CHOICE-2: Smaller diameter, lower current, and short arc reduce heat input on thin material.

stem: After a vertical‑up E7018 pass you see ‘wagon tracks’ of slag along the toes. What should you adjust?

choices.text: Add brief toe pauses, slightly reduce current, and improve interpass cleaning

rationales.CHOICE-3: Toe pauses and cleaning prevent slag traces trapped along bead edges.

stem: You need high deposition on an 8 mm fillet in flat/horizontal. Which E7018 diameter is a good choice?

rationales.CHOICE-3: Ø4.0 mm offers higher deposition in flat/horizontal while remaining manageable.

stem: In the flat position with E7018 you typically travel by…

rationales.CHOICE-2: A slight drag angle is common for 7018 — steadier puddle and slag control.

stem: Your electrode holder is running hot; the jaws burn every 2–3 rods. What should you do?

choices.text: Greatly lower current and ‘stretch’ the rods
Check/tighten the cable connection and repair/replace the holder
Periodically wet the holder with water

rationales.CHOICE-3: Poor contact/worn jaws cause heating and voltage drop — service or replace the holder and fix the cable lug.

stem: You’re unsure about the dryness of E7018 from an open container. Practical step:

choices.text: If the coating looks shiny, they’re dry
Use a fresh pack from the oven; return the suspect batch for rebake per datasheet and check batch/date
Heat the tips to red with a torch
Dip the tip in oil for ‘protection’

rationales.CHOICE-2: When in doubt, weld with verified dry rods and rebake or replace the open batch per instructions.

stem: What starting current should you choose for E7018 Ø4.0 mm (5/32 in) in the flat position on an ~10 mm fillet?

rationales.CHOICE-2: For Ø4.0 mm E7018 a common range is ~130–180 A; start mid‑range and tune by puddle response.

stem: You only have an AC transformer. You need an open‑root on slightly rusty steel. What should you choose?

choices.text: E7018 on AC with no prep
E7024 on AC with a wide weave

rationales.CHOICE-2: E6011 is designed for AC and tolerates light contamination — suitable for roots.

stem: During an E6010 root the keyhole became too large and unstable. First corrective action?

choices.text: Slightly reduce current, shorten the arc, and use a smaller whip‑and‑pause
Switch to E7018 right in the root
Force the rod into the opening aggressively

rationales.CHOICE-2: Less heat and a short arc stabilize the keyhole and prevent burn‑through.

stem: Bevel and root gap are out of WPS tolerance (gap ~5 mm vs 2–3 mm). Proper action?

choices.text: Compensate with higher current and a wide weave
Stop and correct the prep/gap or use a permitted backing method per WPS
Knock off tacks on one side only
Lay a wide cap over it and continue

rationales.CHOICE-2: Nonconformances to the WPS are corrected before welding — fix fit‑up or apply an approved backing.

stem: Your multipass weld has excessive reinforcement (a high cap). How do you prevent this on the next sections?

choices.text: Slightly reduce current/weave amplitude and increase travel speed; use stringers
Peen the reinforcement with a hammer
Make mid‑bead stops to cool the puddle

rationales.CHOICE-2: Lower heat input and stringer beads help form a flatter cap without overlaps.

stem: On a horizontal fillet you see overlap along the lower toe. What should you adjust first?

choices.text: Reduce speed further and lengthen the arc
Slightly increase speed/current, keep a short arc, and hold the correct angle toward the lower toe

rationales.CHOICE-2: Overlap is excess metal without fusion; a short arc, proper angle, and enough energy into the toe eliminate it.

stem: Near the end of the weld at a corner you get magnetic arc blow. What can you do on site without changing the power source?

choices.text: Lengthen the arc and raise current
Move the work clamp closer to the end, run a short arc, and use short stitches/backstep
Change to the largest electrode diameter

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short current paths and a short arc reduce magnetic effects; backstep helps stabilize the puddle.

stem: Outdoor wind and your E7018 cap shows porosity. First step?

choices.text: Shield the area from wind and verify dry electrodes/clean edges
Move the work clamp to another part

rationales.CHOICE-2: Wind, moisture, or dirt cause pores — screen the weld, use dry rods, and ensure clean metal.

stem: WPS: interpass ≤250 °C. You measured 270 °C. What’s correct?

choices.text: Let it air‑cool or blow with air to below the limit, then continue

rationales.CHOICE-1: Cool naturally/with air until within spec; water quenching is not permitted.

stem: What is a typical ‘holding’ temperature for low‑hydrogen electrodes in a jobsite oven?

rationales.CHOICE-2: E7018 are commonly held ~120–150 °C; follow the brand datasheet/WPS.

stem: Inverter settings: ‘Hot Start’ and ‘Arc Force’ for E7018 vertical‑up. Preferred approach?

choices.text: Hot Start minimum, Arc Force maximum
Moderately raise Hot Start and Arc Force, watching the puddle and toes
Hot Start maximum, Arc Force minimum

rationales.CHOICE-3: Moderate boosts ease ignition and puddle control without causing undercut.

stem: Long butt: how should you place tack welds to minimize distortion and keep the root gap?

choices.text: Short, even tacks every 75–150 mm with a symmetric sequence
One long tack along the whole seam
Tacks only at the beginning and end

rationales.CHOICE-2: Frequent short tacks hold alignment and the gap uniformly.

stem: A common sequence for a 10 mm V‑groove with no backing is:

choices.text: A single wide E7018 weave from the start
E6010 root → hot pass → fill with stringers → E7018 cap

rationales.CHOICE-2: Typical practice: a cellulosic root followed by low‑hydrogen fill and cap.

stem: How do you correctly verify an 8 mm fillet weld size with a fillet gauge?

choices.text: Lay the gauge on the bead and eyeball it
Use the 8 mm leaf so both legs and the face contact the gauge with no light gap
Measure the bead diagonal with a tape
Measure only one leg on one side

rationales.CHOICE-2: Full contact on both legs and face without daylight confirms the fillet size.

stem: WPS requires DCEP for E7018, but you welded a section on AC (the brand allows AC). What should you do?

choices.text: Leave it — the rod can run on AC
Consult the responsible engineer; if out of WPS, remove and re‑weld on DCEP
Just lay a DCEP cap over it without removal

rationales.CHOICE-2: The WPS governs; deviations require evaluation and typically repair to the specified polarity.

stem: Overhead (4G) open‑root with E6010: you get periodic burn‑throughs. What helps first?

choices.text: Increase current and dwell over the keyhole
Slightly reduce current, shorten the arc, reduce whip amplitude; a copper backing is acceptable
Hold a long arc so it ‘cools’

rationales.CHOICE-2: Lower heat and a small whip stabilize the root; copper backing can help in overhead.

stem: Joint edges are painted/oily. Proper prep for SMAW?

choices.text: Raise current by 20% and burn through contaminants
Clean to bright metal 10–20 mm each side and degrease with an approved solvent
Do nothing — the cap will cover it
Coat heavily with machine oil for protection

rationales.CHOICE-2: Clean, dry metal reduces porosity and defects; do not ‘burn off’ contaminants.

stem: 2F (horizontal fillet). How should you hold the electrode to counter gravity and avoid undercut?

choices.text: Work angle ~45°, 5–10° drag travel angle, slight lean toward the upper member
Push 30° downward toward the lower member
Use a wide fast weave across both legs

rationales.CHOICE-1: A small lean toward the upper piece with a slight drag angle stabilizes the puddle in 2F.

stem: You find a ‘hi‑lo’ (misalignment) of ~2 mm; WPS allows ≤1 mm. What should you do?

choices.text: Compensate with higher current and ‘fill’ it
Break tacks/re‑fit or dress edges to meet the WPS tolerance
Shift the bead axis with a wide weave
Do nothing — the cap will level it

rationales.CHOICE-2: Fix misalignment before welding or between passes; do not ‘fill’ geometry errors.

stem: Inspection found a slag inclusion in the fill. Proper repair?

choices.text: Lay an additional cap over it
Gouge/grind to sound metal and re‑weld per WPS
Heat with a torch to melt the inclusion

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove the defect to sound metal and re‑weld in accordance with the procedure.

stem: The arc feels soft and unstable: total welding lead length is ~40 m and current is 140 A. What should you do first?

choices.text: Add another 20 m of lead — more length is fine
Install a step-up transformer on the output
Increase cable cross-section or double up the leads, shorten the run, and move the power source/work clamp closer

rationales.CHOICE-3: Voltage drop on long/thin leads chokes the arc; fix by larger conductors and shorter return path.

stem: A supply extension cord was left coiled on its reel; the cord runs hot and the arc sags. What’s the proper action?

choices.text: Fully uncoil the reel and verify the cord gauge is adequate
Wrap the reel in foil to cool it
Add a second extension cord in series

rationales.CHOICE-2: Coiled cords overheat and cause voltage drop; uncoil fully and use proper gauge.

stem: E6010 struggles on an inverter: hard starts and the arc dies. Practical fix?

choices.text: Switch to DCEN and lengthen the arc
Enable the cellulosic/6010 mode or raise Arc Force (Dig), or use E6011 instead
Use a larger-diameter electrode at the same current

rationales.CHOICE-2: Many inverters need a special 6010 profile or higher Dig; E6011 is more forgiving on standard inverters.

stem: Open-root E6010 without backing: after the root you see ‘icicles’ on the backside. How should you correct technique on the fly?

choices.text: Slightly reduce current, shorten the arc, and reduce whip amplitude
Hold a long arc to ‘cool’ the puddle
Force the rod aggressively into the keyhole

rationales.CHOICE-2: Backside icicles indicate excess heat/metal; a short arc and smaller whip stabilize the keyhole.

stem: After an E6010 root you see small ‘dog-ears’ at the edges. Before a E7018 hot pass you should:

choices.text: Melt them out with E7018 without cleaning
Feather the edges lightly by grinding and remove slag to bright metal
Do nothing — the hot pass will wash it out

rationales.CHOICE-2: Feathering and thorough cleaning help avoid lack of fusion and ‘wagon tracks’.

stem: After cooling you find a crater crack on a vertical E7018 weld. Proper repair?

choices.text: Lay an extra bead over it ‘for strength’
Gouge/grind the crack out to sound metal and re‑weld per WPS
Leave it if the crack is small

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cracks must be removed to sound metal and re‑welded; capping over a crack is unacceptable.

stem: 2G (horizontal groove) with E7018: the bead sags and you get undercut at the top toe. What should you adjust?

choices.text: Lean slightly toward the upper toe, add short toe pauses, and keep a short arc
Hold a long arc to reduce heat

rationales.CHOICE-2: A slight lean toward the upper member with brief toe pauses stabilizes the puddle and prevents undercut.

stem: Your electrode stuck to the work. How do you free it without damaging the machine or the work?

choices.text: De‑energize/release current, twist the rod, and gently break it free
Hammer the holder against the work until it lets go
Splash water on the stick point

rationales.CHOICE-2: First remove current, then twist/break off to avoid damaging contacts or the work.

stem: Before bend tests on a plate coupon, what should be done to the weld and specimens?

choices.text: Grind reinforcement flush, remove backing (if any), and break edges/deburr the specimens
Cut a V‑groove down the center to act as a notch

rationales.CHOICE-2: For valid bends, remove cap/root reinforcement, remove backing, and dress sharp specimen edges.

stem: You welded with a backing bar. How should it be removed and prepared for NDE/testing?

choices.text: Knock it off with a sledge — fastest
Burn it off with a torch along the seam
Remove mechanically and grind the root to a smooth surface without notches or undercut
Leave it — it won’t affect results

rationales.CHOICE-3: Remove backing carefully and finish to a smooth, notch‑free surface for reliable inspection.

stem: A tack on the root cracked under heat. What should you do before continuing?

choices.text: Place another tack right over it
Remove the cracked tack completely and install a new correctly sized tack
Weld over it — the crack will fuse out
Close the gap and weld without tacks

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cracked tacks must be removed and replaced; otherwise the defect propagates into the root.

stem: You used magnetic squares for fit‑up. Near the end the arc is blowing off. What should you do?

choices.text: Leave the magnets — they hold alignment
Remove the magnets before welding that section, move the work clamp closer, and run a short arc
Lengthen the arc and raise current
Switch to a larger electrode diameter

rationales.CHOICE-2: Magnets exacerbate arc blow; remove them, shorten the current path, and keep a short arc.

stem: Arc strikes were found outside the weld zone on low‑alloy steel. Proper corrective action?

choices.text: Grind to sound metal, perform NDE (PT/MT) if required, and document per procedure
Peen the marks with a hammer

rationales.CHOICE-2: Arc strikes can create hard spots; remove to sound metal and verify per quality procedure.

stem: Outdoor work at −10 °C on 20 mm carbon steel with E7018. Which set of measures is correct?

choices.text: Minimal preheat on the first pass only
Preheat per WPS, wind shielding, interpass temperature control, and a heated rod quiver
Raise current by 30% with no preheat

rationales.CHOICE-3: Cold conditions speed cooling and raise H‑crack risk; use preheat, wind shields, interpass control, and dry rods.

stem: A continuous line of pores appears along the cap. Likely cause and action?

choices.text: Anti‑spatter/oil contamination — degrease to bright metal and verify dry electrodes

rationales.CHOICE-2: Linear porosity often comes from contamination or moisture; clean thoroughly and use dry 7018.

stem: After the root you detect local lack of fusion. Proper repair before fill passes?

choices.text: Cover it with fill — it won’t be seen
Back‑gouge/air‑carbon gouge to remove the defect and re‑weld the root
Lay a wide bead over the area

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove lack‑of‑fusion defects to sound metal (often by back‑gouging) and re‑establish a sound root.

stem: Tight access inside a box section; E7018 Ø4.0 mm doesn’t fit well and the puddle wanders. Practical solution?

choices.text: Leave as is — tolerances will allow it
Switch to a smaller diameter (3.2/2.5 mm), run short stringers, and keep a short arc
Lengthen the arc and widen the weave

rationales.CHOICE-2: Smaller diameter and short stringers improve control in cramped spaces.

stem: On vertical E7018 you see undercut and a harsh arc. The inverter’s Arc Force (Dig) is set high. What should you do?

choices.text: Reduce Arc Force to a moderate level and keep a short arc with toe pauses

rationales.CHOICE-2: Excessive Dig can wash metal from the toes; moderate settings and proper technique reduce undercut.

stem: Pipe joint: internal hi‑lo is ~1.5 mm; the WPS allows ≤1 mm. What should you do before welding?

choices.text: Shift bead axis with a wide weave and ‘fill it’
Use hi‑lo clamps/line‑up tools to re‑fit within tolerance, then weld
Do nothing — the hot pass will cover it
Increase the root gap to 6 mm and weld without correction

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct misalignment mechanically during fit‑up; you can’t ‘fill away’ geometry errors.

stem: Two welders work on the same structure at once on different seams. Stray currents cause arc strikes and hot spots. Practical solution?

choices.text: Attach both work leads to a nearby column
Provide separate return leads for each station and clamp on the workpiece near each arc
Use a single common work lead — simpler
Place magnets near the weld to stabilize the arc

rationales.CHOICE-2: Separate, short return paths clamped close to each weld prevent stray current through the structure.

stem: How can arc blow be reduced during SMAW?

choices.text: Lengthen the arc and increase current
Shorten the arc, move the work lead, or backstep
Switch to a larger electrode only

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short arcs and better return lead placement reduce magnetic arc blow.

stem: What arc length is generally recommended for SMAW?

choices.text: Very long arc for better visibility
As short as practical, about the electrode diameter

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short arcs improve shielding and reduce spatter and undercut.

stem: For SMAW, which is a recommended arc start method on finished surfaces?

choices.text: Strike on run‑on tabs or within joint area
Strike on machined faces away from joints

rationales.CHOICE-2: Start within joint/tabs to avoid hard spots on faces.

stem: Why remove slag between passes with E7018?

choices.text: It is optional; slag burns out
To avoid slag inclusions and lack of fusion

rationales.CHOICE-2: Slag can become trapped and prevent bonding on subsequent beads.

stem: What problem can damp E7018 electrodes cause?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture in the coating adds hydrogen to the weld pool.

stem: Which polarity is commonly used with E6010?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cellulosic E6010 typically runs on DCEP for deep penetration.

stem: Which technique is typical for open‑root welding with E6010?

choices.text: Fast weave to wash the toes

rationales.CHOICE-2: Whipping controls the keyhole and allows root fusion without excessive burn‑through.

stem: In the designation E7018, what does the '70' indicate?

rationales.CHOICE-3: The first two digits give the minimum tensile strength in ksi.

stem: What coating type characterizes E7018 electrodes?

rationales.CHOICE-2: E7018 is a basic (low‑hydrogen), often iron‑powder type electrode.

stem: Which power source setting can E7018 typically run on?

rationales.CHOICE-2: E7018 is usually suitable for DCEP and often AC depending on brand/WPS.

stem: Which statement describes E7024 electrodes?

rationales.CHOICE-2: E7024 is iron‑powder rutile for high deposition in flat/horizontal.

stem: What are typical angles for a flat fillet weld with SMAW?

choices.text: 90° to both pieces with zero travel angle

rationales.CHOICE-1: A 45° work angle with a slight drag/push travel angle is common.

stem: What hazard is associated with welding galvanized steel?

choices.text: No special hazard compared to bare steel
Zinc fumes; remove coating locally and ensure ventilation

rationales.CHOICE-2: Zinc fumes are hazardous; remove coatings where possible and ventilate adequately.

stem: Why should E7018 electrodes be kept in a heated rod oven between uses?

choices.text: To prevent moisture pickup and hydrogen cracking

rationales.CHOICE-2: Dry storage limits hydrogen pickup that can cause cold cracking.

stem: Which electrode is best suited for deep‑penetration open‑root welding on rusty steel?

rationales.CHOICE-3: Cellulosic E6010 provides deep penetration and tolerance to light surface contamination.

stem: What does the '1' in E7018 indicate?

rationales.CHOICE-3: The position digit '1' means the electrode is usable in all positions.

stem: What is the main benefit of preheating thick or high‑strength steel before welding?

choices.text: It reduces cooling rate and hydrogen cracking risk
It eliminates the need for interpass cleaning

rationales.CHOICE-2: Preheat slows cooling and allows hydrogen to diffuse, lowering crack risk.

stem: What is a good practice when restarting a SMAW bead?

choices.text: Strike on the weld face and continue
Grind/feather the stop and restart slightly ahead to tie in
Do nothing; the slag will float out

rationales.CHOICE-2: Feathering and restarting ahead allow blending without defects.

stem: Which condition commonly leads to undercut in SMAW?

choices.text: Excessive travel speed or a long arc
Low travel speed with short arc

rationales.CHOICE-1: High speed or long arc washes metal away from the toes, creating undercut.

stem: Which technique helps control heat when welding vertical‑up with E7018?

choices.text: Stringer beads (or limited weave) with pauses at the toes

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stringers with brief toe pauses help keep the puddle under control.

stem: A common cause of 'birdnesting' in GMAW wire feeders is:

choices.text: Incorrect drive‑roll tension or liner size causing high drag

rationales.CHOICE-2: Feeding drag or excessive pressure can tangle the wire at the rolls.

stem: What typically causes 'burnback' (wire fusing to the contact tip)?

choices.text: Too short stickout or too slow wire feed relative to voltage

rationales.CHOICE-2: If burnoff exceeds feed, the arc retreats and the wire fuses to the tip.

stem: Reducing CTWD at constant WFS and voltage generally:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Shorter stickout reduces resistive heating, increasing current and penetration.

stem: Excessive stickout/CTWD in GMAW/FCAW causes:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Long stickout increases resistive heating, lowering current.

stem: Which drive rolls are appropriate for FCAW‑S vs solid wire?

choices.text: V‑groove for FCAW‑S; knurled for solid
Knurled for FCAW‑S; V‑groove for solid

rationales.CHOICE-2: Knurled rolls grip tubular wire; V‑groove rolls suit solid steel wire.

stem: In ER70S‑6, what does '70' indicate?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Like SMAW, the '70' refers to minimum tensile strength in ksi.

stem: Most self‑shielded FCAW wires run on:

rationales.CHOICE-1: Popular self‑shielded classifications (e.g., E71T‑8) use DCEN.

stem: Excessive shielding gas flow can:

choices.text: Cause turbulence and aspiration of air

rationales.CHOICE-2: Too much flow creates turbulence that pulls air into the arc.

stem: Which polarity is standard for GMAW and most gas‑shielded FCAW wires?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Solid and gas‑shielded flux‑cored wires typically use electrode positive (DCEP).

stem: In short‑circuit GMAW, increasing inductance generally:

choices.text: Makes the arc harsher with more spatter
Softens the arc and reduces spatter

rationales.CHOICE-2: Greater inductance slows current rise, reducing explosive short clearing and spatter.

stem: For soft wires (aluminum), which liner is appropriate?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Low‑friction liners reduce drag and shavings with soft wire.

stem: Metal‑cored (MCAW) wires typically require:

rationales.CHOICE-2: MCAW wires need the correct shielding gas mix per specification.

stem: Why keep the GMAW nozzle and contact tip clean?

choices.text: To maintain gas coverage and stable electrical contact

rationales.CHOICE-2: Spatter buildup disturbs shielding and electrical continuity.

stem: Which can cause porosity in GMAW?

choices.text: Drafts, improper gas flow, or surface contamination

rationales.CHOICE-1: Shielding disruption and contaminants allow gas pores to form.

stem: A limitation of short‑circuit GMAW on thick plate is:

choices.text: Potential lack of fusion in grooves/fillets

rationales.CHOICE-3: Low energy per droplet can leave lack‑of‑fusion in heavy sections.

stem: Why use a spool gun with aluminum GMAW?

choices.text: To keep soft wire feed path short, reducing birdnesting

rationales.CHOICE-2: A short feed path in the gun reduces feeding issues with soft wire.

stem: To achieve spray transfer on carbon steel, what is generally required?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Spray transfer needs an argon‑dominant gas and sufficient current/voltage.

stem: Which transfer mode provides a continuous stream of metal droplets at high current?

rationales.CHOICE-3: Spray transfer delivers fine droplets axially across the arc.

stem: Increasing travel speed (all else equal) results in:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Higher speed reduces heat input and penetration.

stem: Increasing voltage in CV GMAW (at fixed WFS) tends to:

choices.text: Narrow and stiffen the arc with deeper penetration
Widen the bead and increase wetting
Lower heat input and widen the bead

rationales.CHOICE-2: Higher voltage broadens the arc column, improving sidewall wetting.

stem: In a CV GMAW system, which control primarily changes welding current?

rationales.CHOICE-2: At constant voltage, increasing WFS raises current and deposition rate.

stem: Deep bevel, limited access: shielding gas is blowing off and edges are discoloring. What should you do first?

choices.text: Increase flow to 25–30 L/min — the more, the better
Install a gas lens and a larger cup (e.g., #12), keep 6–10 mm stickout and 8–12 L/min flow
Remove the cup and weld without it — less restriction
Angle the torch 45° away from the joint — the stream will wrap better

rationales.CHOICE-2: A gas lens straightens the flow and a larger cup increases coverage; excessive flow creates turbulence.

stem: What electrode stickout is acceptable when using a gas lens with a #8–12 cup in tight areas?

choices.text: 8–15 mm with stable flow and correct angle
Only flush with the cup edge
More than 25 mm — better puddle view

rationales.CHOICE-2: A gas lens allows safely increasing stickout without losing shielding; excessive stickout degrades coverage.

stem: Root pass on stainless pipe Ø25–30 mm. What back purge at the start is typically adequate?

choices.text: No back purge is needed for TIG

rationales.CHOICE-2: A localized, steady 3–6 L/min purge forms an inert cushion without turbulence or waste.

stem: ‘Sugar’ (crystalline oxide) appeared on the stainless root. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Insufficient/absent back purge or leaks in the dams

rationales.CHOICE-2: ‘Sugar’ is almost always due to poor backside shielding allowing O₂/moisture to reach the puddle.

stem: How do you properly fill out the crater at the end of a bead on thin material?

choices.text: Snap the pedal off to zero — the puddle will freeze itself
Use a stepped slope‑out and add a drop of filler into the crater
Turn purge off early — it cools faster
Run the puddle off the part into the air

rationales.CHOICE-2: Smooth current decay plus feeding the crater reduces end‑crater shrinkage and cracking.

stem: Working in a tight position (overhead/inside a shell), the pedal is inaccessible. How do you control heat?

choices.text: Use a torch‑mounted amperage control (slider/roller) or a programmed on‑torch current profile

rationales.CHOICE-2: On‑torch control/programming lets you meter current when a foot pedal can’t be used.

stem: How should tungsten be ground for DCEN on steel to get a stable arc?

choices.text: Longitudinally along the axis, with a small flat at the tip
Don’t grind at all — a ball is better
As sharp as possible with no flat

rationales.CHOICE-2: Longitudinal grind marks guide electron flow; a slight flat stabilizes the tip.

stem: Which tungsten tip geometry is the most versatile for DCEN on steel?

choices.text: Very sharp 20–30° point with no flat
A 60–90° cone with a ~0.1–0.3 mm flat

rationales.CHOICE-2: A medium cone with a small flat provides a stable arc and predictable bead width.

stem: For a #8 cup on steel in the flat position, what argon flow commonly works right away?

rationales.CHOICE-2: For a #8 cup, 6–8 L/min is typical; too much flow tends to cause turbulence.

stem: On aluminum (AC) you see a white oxide crust and the puddle won’t break through. What should you adjust first?

choices.text: Decrease the EP portion in balance
Increase the EP (cleaning) portion in the AC balance

rationales.CHOICE-2: More EP strengthens cathodic cleaning to break the aluminum oxide.

stem: You need to narrow the arc on aluminum (AC) when welding into a corner. What helps?

choices.text: Increase AC frequency to about 120–200 Hz
Remove the flat on the tungsten

rationales.CHOICE-2: Higher AC frequency narrows the arc column and improves control in corners.

stem: Thin stainless 1.0 mm is warping and discoloring. What should you do?

choices.text: Increase current and speed to get through faster
Use copper backers/heat sinks, keep a short arc and reduce heat input
Downsize to a #4 cup and 1 L/min flow

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cold backers and a short arc reduce heat input, distortion, and heat tint.

stem: What pre‑flow is usually sufficient to start without oxidation when using a #6–8 cup?

rationales.CHOICE-2: A short pre‑flow fills the cup with argon and lowers contamination risk at ignition.

stem: A rule of thumb for post‑flow to protect the weld and cool the tungsten is:

choices.text: 1 s per 10 A, but not less than 5 s

rationales.CHOICE-2: This protects the hot electrode and weld; exact values depend on material and cup.

stem: Sheet thickness 2.0 mm (mild steel, DCEN). Which filler diameter is a good starting point?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Around 1.6 mm filler is commonly comfortable on ~2 mm stock with predictable heat input.

stem: Titanium welding: which colors on the surface after welding indicate adequate shielding?

choices.text: Straw/silver are acceptable; blue/gray call for rework/cleaning
Any colors are fine with argon

rationales.CHOICE-2: Titanium is sensitive to O₂/N₂ at high temperature; light colors can be acceptable, dark colors indicate poor shielding.

stem: For the ‘walking the cup’ technique on pipe, what is critical for stability?

choices.text: A large torch angle of about 45°
Cup support contact and short rocking steps with a short arc
The longest arc possible for visibility

rationales.CHOICE-2: Supporting and rocking the cup in short steps maintains shielding and an even arc gap.

stem: When is it reasonable to switch to a water‑cooled torch?

choices.text: At currents up to 80 A on thin sheet
For prolonged work around ~200 A and above / high duty cycle
When there is no water supply — for versatility

rationales.CHOICE-2: Water cooling reduces handle/cable heating and increases duty cycle at higher currents.

stem: On DC the arc is ‘pulling’ to one side (magnetic arc blow). What should you try first?

choices.text: Move the work lead closer to the weld zone and change the travel direction

rationales.CHOICE-2: Relocating the return clamp and altering current path reduces magnetic field asymmetry.

stem: TIG root on pipe with back purge. To what oxygen level inside do you aim before starting?

choices.text: ≈0.1% O₂ (≤1000 ppm) or lower, per requirements
O₂ level isn’t important as long as there’s purge flow

rationales.CHOICE-2: Low O₂ promotes a bright, clean root; the target threshold is defined by the spec/standard.

stem: Closed stainless pipe purge: where should you place the purge inlet and vent to displace air efficiently?

choices.text: Inlet at the top, vent at the bottom with a large opening
Inlet at the lowest point, a small vent at the highest point
Both inlet and vent at the highest point
No vent; seal completely for maximum purity

rationales.CHOICE-2: Argon is heavier than air; feeding from low and venting at high allows air to be pushed out smoothly.

stem: Open‑root TIG on 1.5" stainless pipe: the root sugars despite 15 L/min purge flow. What should you adjust first?

choices.text: Increase purge to 25 L/min to flood the cavity
Reduce purge to ~3–6 L/min and seal leaks at dams/tape
Switch to CO₂ as a purge gas

rationales.CHOICE-3: Excessive purge flow creates turbulence that drags air in; gentle laminar flow and tight seals prevent oxidation.

stem: Acceptable pre‑clean before TIG on stainless?

choices.text: Wipe with acetone and use a stainless‑only wire brush
Spray chlorinated brake cleaner right before welding
Wipe with a used oily rag to lubricate the joint
Grind with a wheel previously used on carbon steel

rationales.CHOICE-1: Solvent wipe and dedicated stainless tools avoid contamination and oxide‑forming residues.

stem: You dipped the tungsten, the tip is black, and the arc wanders. What’s the correct recovery?

choices.text: Keep welding; it will burn clean
Quench the hot tungsten in water and continue
Stop, clip back the contaminated tip, and re‑grind longitudinally
Sand the tip with emery cloth and continue

rationales.CHOICE-3: Mechanical removal and proper longitudinal grinding restore arc focus and cleanliness.

stem: Approximate tungsten diameter for ~180 A DCEN on mild steel with a steady duty cycle?

rationales.CHOICE-3: A 2.4 mm tungsten typically covers ~150–200 A DCEN with stable tip geometry.

stem: AC TIG on 6 mm aluminum: stubborn oxide and black smut appear. First control to tweak?

choices.text: Increase EP (cleaning) percentage in AC balance
Lower the AC frequency to 20 Hz

rationales.CHOICE-2: More EP increases cathodic cleaning to break the aluminum oxide film.

stem: You need deeper penetration on thick aluminum but you’re current‑limited by duty cycle. Gas choice?

choices.text: Pure helium shielding at the same flow
Ar/He mix (≈25–50% He) to boost heat input and penetration

rationales.CHOICE-2: Helium in the mix raises arc voltage/enthalpy, improving penetration without raising amperage as much.

stem: With a #12 gas lens cup in a light draft, what argon flow is a good starting point?

rationales.CHOICE-3: Large cups often need ~10–12 L/min; too much flow can turn turbulent and entrain air.

stem: You’re inside equipment with sensitive electronics nearby. Which TIG arc start reduces EMI risk?

choices.text: Manual contact start with hot tungsten

rationales.CHOICE-3: Lift‑arc limits high‑frequency interference while providing clean starts.

stem: Vertical‑up fillet on 3 mm stainless is overheating and sagging. Practical control to stabilize the puddle?

choices.text: Enable low‑frequency pulse (≈1–2 Hz) with a lower base current
Hold a longer arc for more visibility
Switch to a larger cup with much higher gas flow
Push travel speed to the maximum

rationales.CHOICE-1: Pulsing freezes the puddle periodically and reduces overall heat input.

stem: Best practice for filler wire handling before TIG on stainless?

choices.text: Keep rods loose on the bench; wipe occasionally with an oily rag
Store in a clean tube; wipe with acetone just before use
Rub rods with carbon steel wool for ‘activation’
Dust with talc to reduce sticking

rationales.CHOICE-2: Clean, sealed storage and solvent wipe reduce contamination and porosity.

stem: On an inverter AC TIG, which tungsten and tip geometry give a stable, narrow arc on aluminum?

choices.text: 2% lanthanated, tapered with a small flat

rationales.CHOICE-2: Modern inverters run well with pointed/landed lanthanated tips, giving focused AC arcs.

stem: Thick 12 mm aluminum plate is cold‑starting and porosity‑prone. A practical mitigation?

choices.text: Preheat to roughly 120–150°C to reduce start‑up chill
Switch to DCEN for a hotter start
Grind the oxide with a wheel used on carbon steel

rationales.CHOICE-1: Moderate preheat improves puddle wet‑in and reduces hydrogen entrapment on heavy sections.

stem: Interpass cleaning for stainless multipass TIG:

choices.text: Stainless‑only brush and solvent wipe before the next pass
Brush with a carbon‑steel wire brush for more bite
No cleaning; slag will float out
Hammer the bead to knock colors off

rationales.CHOICE-1: Dedicated stainless tools and solvent remove heat tint/oxide to prevent lack of fusion.

stem: Your O₂ analyzer at the purge vent shows 0.6% (≈6000 ppm) on a critical stainless root. What now?

choices.text: Begin welding; the torch shielding will handle it
Add more torch post‑flow to compensate
Continue purging until ≤0.1% O₂ (≤1000 ppm) or as per procedure
Drill vent holes to increase air exchange

rationales.CHOICE-3: A low O₂ level at the vent is required for a bright, sugar‑free root per typical procedures.

stem: Joining 304 stainless to mild steel with TIG. Which filler is appropriate?

rationales.CHOICE-2: ER309L is formulated for dissimilar joints from stainless to carbon steel.

stem: Long straight TIG bead on titanium in open air: how to keep colors light beyond the torch cup?

choices.text: Use a trailing shield and extend post‑flow duration
Spray water mist behind the torch
Run with a very long arc for dispersion

rationales.CHOICE-1: A trailing shield protects the hot bead until it cools below oxidation temperature.

stem: Autogenous TIG tack welds show porosity. A simple technique change to try first?

choices.text: Shorten the arc to ≈1–1.5× tungsten diameter and steady the torch
Switch to a larger tungsten without regrinding
Hold the torch farther away for a wider puddle

rationales.CHOICE-1: A short, steady arc improves shielding effectiveness and reduces air entrainment.

stem: Sealing purge dams on a small stainless box: which tape is suitable?

rationales.CHOICE-3: Aluminum foil tape withstands heat and seals well without leaving contaminating residues.

stem: TIG arc drifts due to residual magnetism near lifting magnets on a carbon‑steel fabrication. Immediate fix?

choices.text: Hold a long arc to average it out
Increase gas flow to stabilize the arc
Move the work lead close to the weld path and remove/demagnetize sources

rationales.CHOICE-3: Changing the current path and eliminating magnetic sources reduces arc blow.

stem: Increasing the EP portion of AC balance in GTAW will:

choices.text: Increase oxide cleaning but heat the tungsten more
Reduce cleaning and cool the tungsten

rationales.CHOICE-1: More EP enhances cathodic cleaning and tungsten heating.

stem: Which current is commonly used for GTAW on aluminum?

rationales.CHOICE-2: AC provides EP cleaning action for oxide removal.

stem: Which filler classification is common for GTAW on carbon steel?

rationales.CHOICE-1: ER70S‑2 is a deoxidized filler for GTAW on carbon steel.

stem: What can excessive GTAW shielding gas flow cause?

choices.text: Turbulence that draws in air and contamination

rationales.CHOICE-2: Too much flow creates turbulence and aspiration of air into the shield.

stem: On aluminum GTAW, what provides oxide cleaning action?

rationales.CHOICE-2: The EP half‑cycle breaks the aluminum oxide film during AC welding.

stem: Which polarity is standard for GTAW on carbon steel?

rationales.CHOICE-1: DCEN focuses heat into the work and protects tungsten.

stem: Which gas is commonly used for GTAW shielding and back purging?

rationales.CHOICE-1: Argon is inert and widely used for GTAW and purging.

stem: What prevents 'sugaring' (oxidation) on the backside of stainless GTAW joints?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Inert purge gas shields the backside until the metal cools below oxidation temps.

stem: Which GTAW start method avoids tungsten contamination?

rationales.CHOICE-2: HF or lift‑arc allows non‑contact starts.

stem: Excessive GTAW torch angle typically:

choices.text: Reduces coverage and can cause contamination/undercut

rationales.CHOICE-2: Large angles expose the pool to air and narrow coverage.

stem: If tungsten touches the molten pool, you should:

choices.text: Break off/resharpen tungsten and clean the area

rationales.CHOICE-2: Contamination requires regrinding and cleaning.

stem: How should tungsten be ground for GTAW on steel?

choices.text: With a blunt chisel tip only

rationales.CHOICE-2: Longitudinal grinding directs electrons axially and minimizes arc wander.

stem: Why choose a larger‑diameter tungsten for higher currents?

choices.text: Handle higher heat without melting the tip

rationales.CHOICE-2: Larger tungsten carries more current without overheating.

stem: The end of a weld on 20 mm plate repeatedly cracks across the crater in SAW. What should you do first?

choices.text: Slightly increase arc voltage at the termination
Use run‑off tabs and a crater‑fill/downslope function at stop
Speed up over the last 50 mm
Reduce the flux bed at the exit to a minimum

rationales.CHOICE-2: Run‑off tabs and crater fill prevent shrinkage cracking at the bead end.

stem: A glow is sometimes visible — the flux is not fully covering the arc. What should you do?

choices.text: Increase flux feed/flux ridge height and adjust the guide so the arc is fully buried
Raise voltage for a longer arc
Turn off the vacuum flux‑recovery unit

rationales.CHOICE-2: The arc must be completely submerged in flux for stable shielding and slag formation.

stem: An undercut appears along the upper toe of a fillet weld. What most often helps first?

choices.text: Slightly lower voltage/shorten the arc and adjust the work angle toward the high leg

rationales.CHOICE-2: A long arc and incorrect work angle often cause undercut; a tighter arc and correct angle stabilize the bead.

stem: Burn‑through occurs on an 8 mm wall. How can you reduce penetration without reprogramming the whole procedure?

choices.text: Increase CTWD so some heat is spent preheating the wire (lowering arc current)
Add more flux at the start zone

rationales.CHOICE-2: A greater CTWD reduces current at the arc and penetration without changing the main setpoints.

stem: The bead shows porosity. What is the first action with the flux?

choices.text: Add oil to the flux to bind dust
Dry/rebake the flux per the manufacturer and store it in a dry hopper
Mix spent and fresh flux 1:1 without screening

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture in the flux is a common porosity source; drying and dry storage are required.

stem: What is proper handling of recovered flux?

choices.text: Return it to the hopper immediately with no screening
Screen it, remove slag fines/dust, and blend with new flux within the manufacturer’s allowed ratio
Store it open on the shop floor

rationales.CHOICE-2: Clean reclaimed flux and dose it per spec to avoid degrading weld quality.

stem: On a long girder you notice magnetic arc blow and arc deflection. What is your first practical action?

choices.text: Move the work lead closer/ahead of travel (possibly use two leads) and switch to AC if needed

rationales.CHOICE-2: Optimizing return‑current location and using AC reduces magnetic‑field effects on the arc.

stem: Welding near a plate edge: the flux slides off and shielding is lost. What helps?

choices.text: Lower voltage and remove flux entirely
Use flux dams/retainers and adjust flux feed
Weld without flux with a short arc

rationales.CHOICE-2: Mechanical dams keep flux at the edge and maintain arc coverage.

stem: Lack of root penetration in a double‑V (X) groove on 25 mm plate. Where should you start adjusting?

choices.text: Increase voltage at the same speed
Slightly reduce speed and/or raise current, watching arc shape and the slag shelf
Switch to a larger wire without changing anything else

rationales.CHOICE-2: Lower speed/ higher current increases heat input and penetration; adjust gradually.

stem: The bead is excessively convex (high reinforcement). What is a typical first step?

choices.text: Slightly increase travel speed and/or reduce deposition rate (wire feed)

rationales.CHOICE-2: Excess reinforcement commonly comes from too much deposition; more speed/less feed helps.

stem: Circumferential weld on a rotating pipe: flux gets thrown off at the top quadrant. What should you do?

choices.text: Use flux shoes/retainers and adjust the feed rate
Add water to make the flux heavier
Drop current to zero at top dead center

rationales.CHOICE-2: Mechanical retainers and correct feed prevent flux throw‑off.

stem: At high speed the surface shows a scalloped ‘fish‑scale’ appearance and uneven beads. What should you adjust first?

choices.text: Reduce speed and/or slightly lower voltage for a tighter arc

rationales.CHOICE-2: Excess speed and a long arc produce irregular beads; a tighter arc and moderate speed even them out.

stem: In multipass welding, thoroughly removing slag and flux between passes is essential because…

choices.text: It reduces the risk of slag inclusions and lack of fusion on subsequent passes
You can increase arc voltage without consequences
Flux improves bonding of the next layer

rationales.CHOICE-2: Residual slag/flux commonly causes inclusions and fusion problems.

stem: With long power leads the supply sags and the arc is unstable. What is a practical fix?

choices.text: Increase conductor cross‑section/double the leads and/or move the power source closer

rationales.CHOICE-2: Line losses are offset by larger cables/shorter runs or relocating the power source.

stem: Interpass temperature control on a box girder is critical. Why?

choices.text: To avoid cold cracking/excess heat input and keep mechanical properties within spec
To make the bead more convex
To eliminate the need for cleaning the weld

rationales.CHOICE-2: Temperature control affects hydrogen cracking risk and the weld/HAZ structure.

stem: Flux dust and blow‑off when dropping from excessive height. What is the practical solution?

choices.text: Raise the drop height even more
Lower the flux drop height/adjust the chute and feed, check baffles
Switch to an open‑arc process (no flux)

rationales.CHOICE-2: Shorter drop and proper shielding reduce dispersion and dusting.

stem: After switching to tandem (two‑wire), the bead is wavy with some undercut. What should you target first in setup?

choices.text: Greatly increase voltage on both arcs
Balance lead/lag currents, spacing and offset of arcs, and synchronize wire‑feed speeds
Reduce flux feed to a minimum

rationales.CHOICE-2: In tandem SAW, bead profile depends on lead/lag balance and arc geometry.

stem: Slag inclusions appear between passes in SAW on thick plate. Which is the correct first step?

choices.text: Raise voltage to lengthen the arc
Improve interpass cleaning and adjust travel so slag has time to escape

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cleaning and suitable travel parameters are critical for slag evacuation and avoiding inclusions.

stem: The weld start on a clean edge is cratered with undercut. What is a practical remedy?

choices.text: Start directly on the finished face
Use run‑on tabs and/or a soft‑start current ramp

rationales.CHOICE-2: Run‑on tabs and a gentle current ramp produce a smooth tie‑in without undercut/cratering.

stem: When welding near an open edge the flux periodically falls off and the arc is exposed. Which solution is correct?

choices.text: Weld without flux in that area
Install side shields/dams and slightly reduce speed/voltage for puddle stability
Add water to the flux to make it heavier

rationales.CHOICE-2: Mechanical retention of flux and moderate parameters keep the arc covered at an edge.

stem: In SAW the arc should be:

rationales.CHOICE-1: Full flux coverage ensures shielding and proper slag formation.

stem: What does the flux primarily provide in SAW?

choices.text: Shielding and slag formation around the weld pool

rationales.CHOICE-2: Granular flux provides shielding and slag; it may also add alloying elements.

stem: How should SAW flux be handled to avoid porosity?

choices.text: Keep it dry; if damp, re‑bake per manufacturer instructions
Mix with oil to suppress dust

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture adds hydrogen and causes porosity; flux should be dry, re‑baked if wetted.

stem: An advantage of a multi‑wire SAW system is:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Multiple wires increase deposition and production rate.

stem: Which welding positions are most commonly applicable for submerged arc welding (SAW)?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Granular flux and high deposition rates work best in flat/horizontal positions.

stem: Why is alternating current (AC) often used for SAW at very high currents?

choices.text: To reduce magnetic arc blow and allow higher currents
Because DC cannot produce quality welds
To eliminate the need for flux

rationales.CHOICE-1: AC reduces magnetic field effects on the arc and stabilizes operation at very high currents.

stem: Increasing travel speed in SAW typically:

choices.text: Narrows the bead and reduces penetration

rationales.CHOICE-2: Higher speed lowers heat input and penetration.

stem: Excessive wire stickout in SAW generally:

choices.text: Reduces current and penetration due to resistive heating of the wire

rationales.CHOICE-2: Long stickout heats the wire before the arc, lowering arc current and penetration.
